It unleashes a devastating lightning breath weapon, which strikes in a line 200 feet long and 5 feet wide, capable of annihilating anything in its path. The Huge Blue Dragon's intellect and mastery of magic make it a cunning and dangerous adversary. Its ability to cast spells only adds to the threat it poses, both in the air and on the ground.

Breath Weapon: Lightning, 200 feet long and 5 feet wide, dealing damage equal to the dragon's current hit points.
Terrain: Desert, Rocky Areas
Barding: None

5Ckj0tQTK9DzGBaI.description: The Magic Wand saving throw is used to avoid the effects of attacks or abilities activated through magical wands, such as paralysis rays or damage-dealing beams. A successful save, rolled on a d20, indicates that the character avoids or mitigates the harmful effects. The target number to save is determined by the character's class and level, as found on the saving throw table​​.
5Ckj0tQTK9DzGBaI.name: Magic Wand

Oc45laxy2Wbohu8r.description: The saving throw for Spells or Magic Staff includes resistance against magical effects cast by rods, staves, wands, or through spells. A successful save, rolled on a d20, often reduces or negates the spell's effects entirely. This saving throw is applicable to numerous magical attacks, such as charm spells, fireballs, or paralysis effects, and covers damage, control, or debilitating conditions caused by magical devices or spellcasters. The target number for success is based on the character's class and level.
Oc45laxy2Wbohu8r.name: Spells or Magic Staff

UiLYOsHP8TKPYa6Y.description: The saving throw against Breath Weapons is used to resist or mitigate the effects of a wide range of powerful exhaled attacks, not limited to dragons. This includes attacks like a dragon’s fiery or icy breath, a gorgon's petrifying breath, or a chimera's elemental breath. Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. The target number for the saving throw is determined by the character’s class and level.
UiLYOsHP8TKPYa6Y.name: Dragon Breath

Dragon, White (Large).biography:
The Large White Dragon is a fearsome predator of the frozen wastelands, often encountered in snowy mountains or icy caverns. Its cold breath weapon can engulf its enemies in a freezing cone that extends 80 feet long and 40 feet wide. Though it is less powerful than its larger cousins, its cunning intelligence and frost-covered scales make it a formidable opponent. It can also cast one 1st-level spell, adding a magical threat to its already dangerous presence.

Breath Weapon: Cone of cold, 80 feet long and 40 feet wide.
Terrain: Arctic, Caverns
Barding: None

Paralysis leaves a character aware but unable to act, while petrification turns the character and their carried equipment into a stone statue. Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. Drake, Colddrake.biography:
The Colddrake is a white-scaled drake that lives in icy caverns deep underground, shunning the light of day. It can polymorph into dwarf or gnome forms to blend into underground communities. In drake form, it attacks with two claws and a bite, dealing moderate damage. Colddrakes are highly intelligent and chaotic, using their shape-changing and thief abilities to infiltrate and cause trouble among the dwarves and gnomes with whom they live.

Special Abilities: Immune to all spells of 4th level or lower, but can suppress this immunity for 1 round. They also possess the abilities of a 5th-level thief and can polymorph into dwarf or gnome forms.

Drake, Elemental.biography:
Elemental Drakes are rare and dangerous creatures that hail from the elemental planes. These drakes can polymorph into young giant forms (up to 4 feet shorter than normal giants) on the Prime Plane, or into small elemental forms on their home plane. In drake form, they attack with claws and a bite, dealing significant damage. Elemental Drakes are immune to normal and silver weapons, requiring magical weapons to harm them. They also possess the abilities of a 5th-level thief, making them cunning foes.

Polymorph: On the Prime Plane, Elemental Drakes can polymorph into young giant forms (cloud, stone, fire, or storm giants), but cannot use giant rock-throwing abilities. On their home plane, they transform into small elemental forms with the abilities of a 6 HD elemental.
Elemental Immunities: Immune to normal and silver weapons; only magical weapons can harm them.
Flight: The drake can fly at a speed of 30 feet per turn, but only for 1 hour at a time.
Terrain: Any
Barding: None

Drolem*.biography:
A Drolem is a type of golem that looks like a dragon. It can be made to resemble any dragon color or may appear as a dragon skeleton. Like other golems, it is not alive, but a construct created by a high-level magic-user or cleric. Drolems are extremely rare, typically built to guard a special item or location. A special book and several rare materials are required to create a Drolem.

A Drolem is nonintelligent and follows instructions exactly. It can see invisible creatures within 60 feet and is immune to:

  • Charm, hold, sleep, and all mind-affecting spells
  • All forms of fire, cold, and gases
  • Spells of 4th level or lower
  • All normal and silver weapons, as well as magical weapons of +2 or lesser enchantment

The Drolem's claws inflict 2d6 points of damage each, and its massive jaws cause 11-30 (1d20 + 10) points of damage. It can also breathe a poisonous cloud up to three times per day. The cloud is 20 feet x 20 feet x 20 feet, and creatures within the area must make a saving throw versus dragon breath or die.

Dryad.biography:
Dryads are elusive, beautiful tree spirits inhabiting deep forests. Though peaceful by nature, they are wary of outsiders. If a Dryad wishes to avoid detection, she merges with her tree, becoming part of it. She can cast Charm Person at will, but only uses this power on those who threaten her or on males she finds attractive. Victims of this charm save with a -2 penalty.

Charmed individuals may be sent to deadly ambushes or drawn into her tree. Once inside, victims often disappear unless rescued quickly. Dryads will go to great lengths to protect their trees, as they are bound to them and will die if separated from their tree by more than 240 feet for over a turn. They typically do not carry weapons but may wield a javelin or spear if defending their home.

They store treasures in hidden hollows beneath their tree’s roots. If a Dryad’s tree is threatened, she will often negotiate, releasing any captured individuals rather than risk its destruction.

Terrain: Woods (dense)

A Level 1 Dwarf, standing about 4' tall with a stocky build, typically armed with an axe and wearing heavy armor. Dwarves are known for their craftsmanship and fondness for good food and drink. They can see in the dark (Infravision) up to 60 feet and are resistant to magic with good saving throws.

Efreeti (Greater; Amir)*.biography:
On the elemental plane of Fire, the rulers of the efreet are known as amirs. These mighty beings appear as enormous efreet, standing between 15 and 30 feet tall. Unlike lesser efreet, an amir cannot be harmed by normal weapons or even by magical weapons of less than +2 enchantment. They also regenerate 2 hit points per round.

Amirs possess all the abilities of a lesser efreeti and can use them as often as desired, once per round. Additionally, they can enter or leave the Ethereal Plane by concentrating for one full round.

Once per day, an amir can grant another's wish, cast fireball, or unleash an explosive cloud, all as if cast by a 20th-level magic-user.

Amirs can assume a pillar of flame form without limit, igniting all flammable objects within 15 feet. While in this form, their melee attacks deal an additional 2d8 fire damage.

These beings cannot be summoned by spells and are resistant to most magical items. They rarely appear on the Prime Plane, doing so only in response to the cries of mistreated efreeti. When they do, they can appear anywhere but prefer hot environments such as deserts.

Terrain: Plane of Fire

Load: Flies with up to 10,000 cn at full speed or 20,000 cn at half speed. Walks with up to 20,000 cn at full speed or 40,000 cn at half speed.

  • Poisonous Gas: Each creature in the cloud must make a saving throw vs. spells or be **paralyzed** for 1 round. They may attempt a new saving throw each round.
  • Explosions: The cloud is filled with **tiny detonations**, dealing damage each round to all creatures inside.

Efreeti, Lesser*.biography:
Efreeti are powerful enchanted beings from the elemental plane of Fire. They appear as smoke that condenses into giant-sized humanoids wreathed in flame. The air around them is hot and smoky, and they radiate an aura of menace. Efreeti are highly magical, and can only be harmed by magical weapons. If slain, their spirit returns to the Plane of Fire.

Efreeti can create objects, produce illusions, and turn invisible at will. They can also cast wall of fire up to three times per day. Once per turn, they may transform into a pillar of flame for up to three rounds, setting fire to all flammable items within 5 feet. While in this form, their melee attacks deal an additional 1d8 fire damage.

Summoning an efreeti requires a high-level magic-user with access to both create magical monsters and wish spells. When summoned, the efreeti must serve for 101 days but will seek to twist its master's instructions in ways that cause trouble.

Efreet dwell in grand cities on their home plane, similar to those of wealthy desert-dwelling humans. They despise djinn and will attack them on sight. While generally at peace with fire elementals, they have fought wars against them in the past. Efreet fear water-based creatures and attacks.

Terrain: Plane of Fire

Elemental Ruler, Air (Plane of Air)*.biography:
The supreme rulers of the Elemental Plane of Air, these beings are vast, towering storms, standing 82 feet tall at minimum (2 feet per Hit Die). They oversee massive cloud cities and command the lesser air elementals.

Immense Power: These rulers are immune to 1st-5th level spells, poison, charm, hold, illusions, and all instant-death magic (such as disintegrate). They can only be harmed by +4 weapons or greater.

Crushing Blows: A victim struck by an elemental ruler must make a saving throw vs. death ray or be instantly crushed, regardless of damage taken. Any items they carry have a 95% chance of destruction (-5% per “plus” if magical).

Summoning: Air Elemental Rulers can summon creatures of their plane at will, with reinforcements arriving in 3 rounds to 3 turns.

HD & Scaling: Air Elemental Rulers grow in power as they age:

  • 41-48 HD: AC -11, 8d12 damage per fist, XP 28,500
  • 49-56 HD: AC -12, 9d12 damage per fist, XP 36,500
  • 57-64 HD: AC -13, 10d12 damage per fist, XP 44,500
  • 65-72 HD: AC -14, 11d12 damage per fist, XP 52,500
  • 73-80 HD: AC -15, 12d12 damage per fist, XP 60,500

These beings rarely interact with mortals, ruling their plane with absolute authority.

Terrain: Elemental Plane of Air

Elemental, Air (Plane of Air)*.biography:
Elementals of the Plane of Air exist in a universe made of endless skies, where they live in massive cloud cities and refer to themselves as "people." They are the dominant race of their plane and rule over thousands of floating worlds composed of air, mist, and vapor.

On their home plane, Air Elementals appear as ever-shifting blobs of wind, able to form and reshape their bodies at will. They can create a number of "arms" equal to their Hit Dice but can only attack once per round.

Their size is based on their Hit Dice, ranging from 1 HD (tiny whirling breeze) to 32 HD (vast storm clouds). They can live up to 35 Hit Dice before aging forces them to weaken and disperse.

Elementals generally distrust creatures from the Prime Plane, recognizing them by their scent. However, if a visitor appears in elemental form, the reaction penalty is reduced.

HD & Scaling: Air Elementals range in strength depending on their age and power:

  • 1-2 HD: AC 5, 1d2 damage, XP 20
  • 3-4 HD: AC 4, 1d4 damage, XP 75
  • 5-6 HD: AC 3, 1d6 damage, XP 275
  • 7-8 HD: AC 2, 1d8 damage, XP 650
  • 9-10 HD: AC 1, 2d6 damage, XP 1,000
  • 11-12 HD: AC 0, 2d8 damage, XP 1,250
  • 13-14 HD: AC -1, 2d10 damage, XP 1,500
  • 15-16 HD: AC -2, 3d8 damage, XP 1,850
  • 17+ HD: Gains more power, beyond standard elementals

Some elementals study magic and become powerful spellcasters, but only after reaching 9 HD or higher.

Terrain: Elemental Plane of Air

Elementals of the Plane of Earth live deep within a universe made of endless rock, gemstone, and tunnels. They rule sprawling underground kingdoms of solid stone, where they refer to themselves as "people" and consider themselves the oldest race of all.

On their home plane, Earth Elementals appear as massive shifting forms of stone, able to shape themselves at will. They can form a number of limbs equal to their Hit Dice but can only strike once per round.

Earth Elementals distrust creatures from the Prime Plane, recognizing them by their unnatural movement. However, if a visitor appears in elemental form, the reaction penalty is reduced.

Elemental, Water (Plane of Water)*.biography:
Elementals of the Plane of Water rule over a vast, endless ocean of liquid realms. They inhabit underwater cities made of pure, shifting currents and refer to themselves as the "true fluid lifeforms."

On their home plane, Water Elementals appear as immense moving tides, able to reshape their bodies at will. They can form a number of limbs equal to their Hit Dice but can only strike once per round.

Their size is based on their Hit Dice, ranging from 1 HD (tiny ripple) to 32 HD (massive, city-swallowing tsunami). They live up to 35 Hit Dice before they begin to dissolve into the endless sea.

Water Elementals view Prime Plane creatures as unnatural and alien, sensing their dryness immediately. However, if a visitor appears in elemental form, the reaction penalty is reduced.

HD & Scaling: Water Elementals vary greatly in power:

  • 1-2 HD: AC 5, 1d2 damage, XP 20
  • 3-4 HD: AC 4, 1d4 damage, XP 75
  • 5-6 HD: AC 3, 1d6 damage, XP 275
  • 7-8 HD: AC 2, 1d8 damage, XP 650
  • 9-10 HD: AC 1, 2d6 damage, XP 1,000
  • 11-12 HD: AC 0, 2d8 damage, XP 1,250
  • 13-14 HD: AC -1, 2d10 damage, XP 1,500
  • 15-16 HD: AC -2, 3d8 damage, XP 1,850
  • 17+ HD: Becomes even larger and more powerful

Some Water Elementals become clerics or spellcasters, but only after reaching 9 HD or higher.

Terrain: Elemental Plane of Water

Elephant, Normal.biography:
Elephants are massive, four-legged herbivores that inhabit the edges of sub-tropical forests, living in large herds. Despite their calm nature, they become extremely dangerous when provoked or defending their young.

Elephants attack with a charge whenever possible, dealing double tusk damage. In the following rounds, they have a 75% chance to attack with their tusks and a 25% chance to trample.

Ivory Value: Elephants' tusks are highly valued, selling for 100-600 gp per tusk.

War & Labor: Elephants are sometimes trained as war mounts and can be equipped with barding (cost multiplied by 3x). They are also used as draft and riding animals.

Load Capacity: 9,000 cn at full speed, 18,000 cn at half speed.

War & Hunting: Some primitive cultures hunt mastodons for their meat and ivory, while others train them for war, equipping them with barding (cost multiplied by 3x).

This spell allows the caster to see a glow surrounding all magical objects, creatures, and places within 60'. The caster can see the glow only if the objects are visible; hidden items will not show their glow. No saving throw is allowed.

Example: After casting the spell, a magic-user can see a glowing door (locked by magic) and a glowing potion. A magical wand inside a treasure chest would not be visible as the chest hides its glow.

VwCEZVk0ffpe8Adj.description:
This spell allows the caster to read any magical words or runes, such as those found on scrolls or inscribed on items. It does not allow the caster to speak the words, only to read and understand them. A spellcaster cannot understand unfamiliar magical writings without using this spell.

Once a caster reads a scroll or rune with this spell, they can read or speak that magic again without using this spell. All spell books are written in magical words, and only their owners may read them without using this spell.
VwCEZVk0ffpe8Adj.name: Read Magic

aq3slh0V025PDfGZ.description:
This spell puts 2-16 Hit Dice of creatures to sleep within a 40' square area. It affects creatures with 4+1 HD or less and does not work against undead or very large creatures, such as dragons. Creatures outside the area of effect are not affected.

Slapping, kicking, or shaking a sleeping creature will wake it. A single blow with an edged weapon can kill a sleeping creature, regardless of its hit points.

Your Dungeon Master will roll [[/r 2d8 #Sleep total hit dice affected]] to determine the total Hit Dice or experience levels of creatures affected by the spell. No saving throw is allowed.

The spell will put the targets to sleep for [[/r 4d4 #Sleep duration in turns]] turns.
aq3slh0V025PDfGZ.name: Sleep
aq3slh0V025PDfGZ.spellEffect: 2d8 Hit Dice of living creatures within a 40' square area

This spell affects humans, demihumans, and certain other creatures. The target must make a saving throw vs. spells; if failed, the target views the caster as a “best friend” and will defend them against any perceived threat. The spell does not affect animals, magical creatures, undead, or creatures larger than ogres.

The charmed creature obeys friendly commands but resists those that go against its nature or cause self-harm. The duration depends on the target’s Intelligence, allowing periodic saving throws:

  • High Intelligence (13-18): Save every day
  • Average Intelligence (9-12): Save every week
  • Low Intelligence (3-8): Save every month

Faerie.biography:
Faeries are small, winged humanoids that inhabit the air and clouds. They have traits of multiple races: dwarven noses and beards, elven eyes and ears, and halfling-sized bodies. Their empire in the sky is hidden from most other beings.

Natural Invisibility: Faeries are invisible at all times and cannot be seen with normal sight. However, they can see invisible creatures without difficulty.

Innate Magical Abilities: Faeries can use the following powers at will, once per round:

  • Assume Gaseous Form: Functions like the potion.
  • Create Fog: Forms a 10' cube of mist around the faerie.
  • Condense Fog: Causes drizzle within the fog.
  • Return to Normal Form: Exits gaseous state.
  • Summon Breeze: Causes flames to flicker, blows out candles, and allows the faerie to fly at 360' (120') for one turn.

Faerie Society: Faeries live in floating homes made of "clouds," enjoying life above the storms. Their empire of wind is known only to them and a few air creatures.

Leaders & Spellcasters: Common faeries have 1+1 HD, but their leaders can have up to 9 HD. Some rare faeries are magic-users or clerics (see "Monster Spellcasters").

Terrain: Any.

Gargoyle*.biography:
Gargoyles are magical constructs, created by wizards to serve various purposes, particularly as guardians. Over time, many gargoyles have escaped or outlived their creators, forming groups and defending their own territories.

Resembling hideous humanoids with horns, claws, fangs, and bat-like wings, gargoyles are often mistaken for statues due to their stone-like skin. Cunning and semi-intelligent, they can remain still for years without need for food or drink, watching over their territory patiently.

Gargoyles are immune to normal weapons, sleep, and charm spells. They can only be harmed by magical weapons and are fiercely territorial, attacking anyone who encroaches on their domain.

Gelatinous Cube.biography:
The gelatinous cube is a massive, nearly invisible ooze that moves through dungeon corridors, consuming all organic material in its path.

Surprise Attack: Due to its transparency, it is difficult to see, surprising foes on a roll of 1-4 (on 1d6).

Paralysis Attack: If a creature is struck, it takes 2d4 damage and must make a saving throw vs. paralysis or be paralyzed for 2d4 turns. A paralyzed creature is automatically hit.

Absorption: The cube picks up weapons, coins, and other non-digestible objects as it moves. These may be visible inside its form.

Resistances: The gelatinous cube is immune to cold and lightning.

Reproduction: Gelatinous cubes reproduce by splitting into two full-sized adults; no smaller or "young" cubes exist.

Terrain: Cavern, Ruins.

Ghoul.biography:
Ghouls are hideous, bestial undead that hunger for the flesh of the living. They retain no real memories of their past lives, act like ravenous predators, and are incapable of speech.

Undead Nature: Ghouls are immune to sleep and charm spells.

Paralyzing Attacks: Any creature ogre-sized or smaller (except elves) hit by a ghoul must make a saving throw vs. paralysis or be paralyzed for 2d4 turns. A ghoul will ignore paralyzed victims to attack other opponents.

Sunlight Aversion: While not harmed by the sun, ghouls avoid daylight and prefer to hunt at night.

Scavengers: When living prey is unavailable, ghouls feast on rotting flesh and carrion.

Terrain: Cavern, Ruins.

Giant, Cloud.biography:
Cloud giants are fierce beings with white or gray skin and hair. Standing 20 feet tall, they wear pale robes and possess keen eyesight and a sharp sense of smell, making them difficult to surprise (only 1 chance in 6). They are capable of throwing boulders at ranges of 60, 130, or 200 feet. These giants reside in castles built into mountainsides or perched atop massive clouds.

As guards, they keep either [[/r 1d6 #Small roc guards]] small rocs (if in clouds or mountains) or [[/r 6d6 #Dire wolf guards]] dire wolves (only in mountains).

Cloud giants despise being disturbed and often block mountain passes to discourage trespassers.

Giant Weapon Damage: 6d6.
Rock Damage: 3d6, up to 200 range.
Terrain: Clouds or Mountains.

Giant, Fire.biography:
Fire giants have red skin, dark black hair, and thick beards. Standing 16 feet tall, they wear armor made of copper, brass, or bronze. They frequently throw rocks at ranges of 60, 130, or 200 feet. These giants typically dwell near volcanoes or other intensely hot environments, with their castles often constructed from black baked mud reinforced with crude iron.

As guards, they always have either [[/r 1d100 #Hydra guards if roll equal to or under 20, otherwise Hellhound guards]] [[/r 1d3 #Hydra guards]] hydras (20%) or [[/r 3d6 #Hellhound guards]] hellhounds (80%).

They are completely immune to fire-based attacks.

Rock Damage: 3d6, up to 200 range.
Terrain: Volcanoes, Intensely Hot Environments.

Giant, Sea (10HD).biography:
Sea giants are typically amicable beings, though they are seldom encountered as they prefer to inhabit the deepest trenches of the ocean. They bear a striking resemblance to humans, aside from their towering height of 15 to 20 feet. These giants can breathe underwater but are capable of holding their breath for up to a full turn when briefly leaving the sea, a rare occurrence. Although they can wield weapons, usually massive spears dealing 1d10 × 4 damage, they seldom do so.

A remarkable ability of sea giants is their control over water currents. Underwater, they can generate a powerful surge in a cone extending 50 feet long and 30 feet wide at the base, forcefully propelling everything within the area 60 feet away without allowing a saving throw. Each affected creature must make a saving throw vs. death ray or be stunned for [[/r 1d6 #Rounds stunned by water surge]] rounds. On the ocean surface, this effect transforms into a massive wave measuring 120 feet long and 60 feet wide at its base, capable of dealing [[/r 2d6 #Hull points of damage]] hull points of damage to any vessel in its path​.

Terrain: Deep Sea.

These giants can breathe underwater but are capable of holding their breath for up to a full turn when briefly leaving the sea, a rare occurrence. Although they can wield weapons, usually massive spears dealing 1d10 × 4 damage, they seldom do so.

A remarkable ability of sea giants is their control over water currents. Underwater, they can generate a powerful surge in a cone extending 50 feet long and 30 feet wide at the base, forcefully propelling everything within the area 60 feet away without allowing a saving throw. Each affected creature must make a saving throw vs. death ray or be stunned for [[/r 1d6 #Rounds stunned by water surge]] rounds. On the ocean surface, this effect transforms into a massive wave measuring 120 feet long and 60 feet wide at its base, capable of dealing [[/r 2d6 #Hull points of damage]] hull points of damage to any vessel in its path​.

Terrain: Deep Sea.

Giant, Storm.biography:
Storm giants are the tallest of all giants, often standing over 22 feet tall. They have bronze-colored skin with bright red or yellow hair. They rarely [[/r 1d100 #Giant throws boulder if roll equal to or under 10]] (10%) throw boulders, with ranges of 150, 300, or 450 feet. Passionate about thunderstorms, they can create one in just 1 turn. If a storm is already present, a storm giant can unleash a lightning bolt once every 5 rounds, dealing damage equal to their remaining hit points (a successful saving throw vs. spells reduces this damage by half). These giants make their homes on mountaintops, in cloud castles, or deep underwater.

Their castles are always guarded by either [[/r 2d4 #Griffon guards]] griffons (if in mountains or clouds) or [[/r 3d6 #Giant crab guards]] giant crabs (if underwater).

Immune to lightning, storm giants are often found in the heart of violent storms, reveling in the chaos of the weather.

Gnoll.biography:
Gnolls are large, ferocious humanoids with low intelligence. They resemble a cross between a human and a hyena, and are often found in rough, rugged wasteland or wilderness areas. Though they are strong, they are lazy, preferring to bully and steal rather than work. Most gnolls do not craft their own metal weapons, instead stealing them from humans.

For every group of 20 gnolls, one will be a leader with 16 hit points who fights as a monster with 3 Hit Dice. Gnolls are rumored to have originated from a magical combination of a gnome and a troll created by an evil magic-user.

Gnome (1HD).biography:
Gnomes are small humanoids closely related to dwarves, standing about 3 1/2' to 4' tall with long noses and full beards. They typically live in burrows or underground cities and are known for their craftsmanship.

Infravision: Gnomes have well-developed infravision with a 90' range.

Smiths & Miners: Excellent metalworkers, gnomes have a deep love for gold and gems and sometimes take risks to obtain them. They also have a keen interest in machinery.

Preferred Weapons: Gnomes favor crossbows and war hammers in combat.

Enemy of Kobolds & Goblins: Gnomes consider these creatures thieves and will attack kobolds on sight.

Leadership Bonuses:

  • For every 20 gnomes, one is a leader with 11 HP, fighting as a **2 HD monster**.
  • In gnome villages, the **clan chieftain (18 HP, attacks as 4 HD, +1 damage)** is protected by **1d6 bodyguards (10-13 HP, attack as 3 HD).**
  • If the **chieftain or leader is alive**, all gnomes within sight have Morale 10 instead of 8.

Gnome Spellcasters: Some gnomes can use magic; see "Monster Spellcasters" for details.

Terrain: Cavern, Open.

At the mid-point of the swing, they let go of the loose end, which releases the pellet. Slings normally require pellets as ammunition, although they can be used with stones taken from the ground, albeit with a –1 penalty on to-hit and damage rolls.

Goblin.biography:
Goblins are small, ugly humanoids standing between 3 1/2 to 4 1/2 feet tall. They have pointed ears, misshapen teeth, and their skin varies from chalky tan to livid gray. Their eyes glow red in dim light, allowing them to see in the dark with infravision up to 90 feet.

Goblins live in underground caves and caverns, and they are uncomfortable in daylight, fighting with a -1 penalty to attack rolls in bright light. They send hunting parties at night to scavenge food and ambush weakly-defended human groups. Goblins hate dwarves, attacking them on sight.

In their lair, a goblin king with 15 hit points leads them. He fights as a 3 HD monster, dealing +1 extra damage. The king is always accompanied by a bodyguard of 2d6 goblins who fight as 2 HD creatures. Goblin morale is improved to 9 when their king is present and alive.

Goblins are small, ugly humanoids standing between 3 1/2 to 4 1/2 feet tall. They have pointed ears, misshapen teeth, and their skin varies from chalky tan to livid gray. Their eyes glow red in dim light, allowing them to see in the dark with infravision up to 90 feet.

Goblins live in underground caves and caverns, and they are uncomfortable in daylight, fighting with a -1 penalty to attack rolls in bright light. They send hunting parties at night to scavenge food and ambush weakly-defended human groups. Goblins hate dwarves, attacking them on sight.

In their lair, a goblin king with 15 hit points leads them. He fights as a 3 HD monster, dealing +1 extra damage. The king is always accompanied by a bodyguard of 2d6 goblins who fight as 2 HD creatures. Goblin morale is improved to 9 when their king is present and alive.

Weapon Damage: By weapon.
Terrain: Cavern, Hill, Mountain, Woods.

3TU6KaLywz359fh6.description: The saving throw against "Stone or Paralysis" protects a character from attacks or effects that could freeze them in place (paralysis) or turn them into stone. If the saving throw is failed, the character becomes immobilized or petrified, depending on the effect. Paralysis leaves a character aware but unable to act, while petrification turns the character and their carried equipment into a stone statue. The duration or permanence of these effects is specified by the source, and successful saving throws avoid them entirely​​​.
3TU6KaLywz359fh6.name: Turn to Stone or Paralysis

3x7q5cLSU1xLO0Dv.description: A short bow is a 3’-4’ bow, either made from a single piece of wood or a composite of different woods. A short bow requires both hands to fire. Bows require the use of arrows as ammunition.

O1DcMM9zd1ZqhA0d.description: The Death Ray or Poison saving throw is a roll made by a character to resist deadly effects like instant death or paralysis from poisons, spells, or traps. A failed roll often results in death (for poison) or other severe consequences, though optional rules may instead inflict substantial damage​​​.

WzZK6sdNYDiB5Wi1.description: The saving throw for Spells or Magic Staff includes resistance against magical effects cast by rods, staves, wands, or through spells. This saving throw is applicable to numerous magical attacks, such as charm spells, fireballs, or paralysis effects, and covers damage, control, or debilitating conditions caused by magical devices or spellcasters. The target number for success is based on the character's class and level.

mg3SETDkxxj1z39H.description: The saving throw against Breath Weapons is used to resist or mitigate the effects of a wide range of powerful exhaled attacks, not limited to dragons. Golem, Bronze*.biography:
The bronze golem is a massive, 16-foot-tall humanoid construct made of solid bronze. It resembles a towering fire giant with glowing, molten veins beneath its metal exterior.

Burning Blood: Any creature that damages the bronze golem with an edged weapon must make a saving throw vs. death ray or take 2d6 damage as fiery blood spurts from the wound.

Fiery Strikes: The bronze golem's melee attacks are superheated, dealing an additional 1d10 fire damage per hit.

Fire Immunity: The bronze golem is completely immune to all fire-based attacks, including magical fire.

Resistances:

  • Immune to sleep, charm, and hold spells.
  • Does not breathe, making it immune to all gas-based attacks.

Terrain: Variable.

A gorgon is a magical bull-like monster covered with large ironlike scales, usually found in hills or grasslands. Gorgons can attack with their great horns or with their breath weapon, a cloud of petrifying vapor extending 60' long and 10' wide. Any creature in the area must make a saving throw vs. turn to stone or be petrified. Gorgons are immune to their own breath weapon and all other petrifying attacks. Native to both the Prime Plane and their original home, the Elemental Plane of Earth, they are terrifying creatures feared for their unique petrifying ability.

Grab grass appears identical to normal tall grass (3'-5' high) but is actually an animated, predatory plant.

Grasping Attack: Anyone who moves into or through grab grass will be restrained as the grass attempts to hold them in place.

Breaking Free: A trapped individual has a 5% chance per round to escape if they have a strength of 12 or lower. For each point of strength above 12, the chance increases by +5% per point (e.g., STR 16 = 25% chance per round).

Destroying the Grass: The grab grass patch has 1 Hit Die per 5' square. Every 8 damage destroys a 5' section.

Grave Worm.biography:
This scavenger, known as a Grave Worm, is a 9-foot-long, 3-foot-high, many-legged creature. It can move effortlessly across floors, walls, and ceilings. Its small mouth is surrounded by eight 2-foot-long tentacles, which can paralyze a victim upon a successful hit unless a saving throw vs. paralysis is made. The tentacles themselves do not inflict any damage.

Grave Worms are notorious scavengers, typically feeding on the remains of dead animals. However, they will eagerly pursue fresh prey if the opportunity arises. They often attack small groups of travelers, paralyzing their victims and consuming them within three turns unless interrupted. The paralysis will naturally wear off in 2d4 turns unless cured magically.

Greater Phoenix*.biography:
Born of the elemental plane of Fire, the Greater Phoenix takes the form of an immense red-orange eagle cloaked in searing flames. Rarely seen on the Prime Plane, it adapts to any climate but eschews underground haunts. It remains tranquil unless challenged.

Impervious to all fire, charm, and hold spells, it also deflects strikes from weapons below +3 enchantment. In combat, it wields its claws and beak, its radiant blaze searing enemies within a 20' radius for [[/r 6d6 #Fire damage per round]], unhindered by fire defenses due to the distinct nature of phoenix flame.

When overcome, the Greater Phoenix bursts in a 20' radius explosion, unleashing [[/r 1d10*10 #Explosion damage]] (save vs. dragon breath for half, bypassing fire protection), then resurrects from its ashes 1 round later, fully renewed, and takes flight to escape. A wish alone can eradicate it permanently; its rebirth cycle is an unsolved enigma.

Each vanquishing yields one feather. A single feather (worth 25,000 gp) crafts a potion of phoenix fire resistance, providing total immunity to normal and magical fire, halving fire breath damage (quarter with a save), and conferring standard resistance to phoenix fire.
Terrain: Any; Plane of Fire

Green Slime*.biography:
The green slime is a horrifying, mindless ooze that clings to ceilings and walls, waiting to drop onto unsuspecting victims.

Always Hit: The green slime is AC 20 and can always be hit by attacks.

Destructive Touch: It dissolves cloth and leather instantly, wood and metal in 6 rounds, but cannot dissolve stone.

Body Transformation: When green slime touches flesh, it sticks and starts transforming the victim into green slime. The process is irreversible after 1d4 rounds unless it is burned off or removed with cure disease.

Burning & Removal: Green slime cannot be scraped off. Fire and cold damage it, but fire also harms the victim (splitting damage between both).

Resistances & Weaknesses:

  • Immune to all attacks except fire or cold.
  • Cannot be harmed by normal weapons.

Terrain: Cavern, Ruins.

Gremlin.biography:
The gremlin is a mischievous, 3-foot-tall humanoid with pasty gray-green skin, saucer-like eyes, and pointed ears. They have an evil sense of humor and love causing mayhem.

Chaotic Aura (20' Radius): Gremlins radiate a powerful aura of chaos, where "anything that can go wrong will go wrong." Each round, all creatures within the aura must save vs. spells or suffer random bad luck (determined by the DM).

Missed Attacks: Any creature that misses an attack against a gremlin must reroll the attack against themselves.

Spell Reversal: Any character casting a spell within the chaotic aura must roll a save vs. spells. If successful, the spell affects the gremlins; if failed, it backfires and affects the caster.

Mechanical Interference: Gremlins love breaking mechanical objects—crossbows might snap, axeheads may fall off, and magical devices may malfunction in bizarre ways.

Gremlin Spellcasters: Some gremlins practice magic; see Monster Spellcasters for details.

Terrain: Any.

Griffon.biography:
Griffons are large, majestic creatures with the head, wings, and front claws of an eagle and the body and hindquarters of a lion. They are known for their fierce nature and have a particular hunger for horses. When within 120 feet of a horse, a griffon must make a morale check or attack immediately.

Griffons are capable of carrying off horse-sized creatures at half their flying speed. Although wild griffons can be tamed if captured young, even trained griffons retain their instinctive urge to attack horses and must check morale when near them.

Terrain: Mountain.
Load: 3,500 cn at full speed, 7,000 cn at half speed.

Halfling.biography:
Halflings are small, demihuman creatures who often live near their villages. They are skilled with missile weapons, receiving a +1 bonus to attack rolls when using them. Halflings are excellent at hiding, particularly in **woods** or **underbrush**, where there is only a 10% chance of being detected while hiding.

In combat, halflings gain a +2 bonus to **Armor Class** when fighting larger than man-sized enemies. For every 10 halflings, one will be a leader of **level 2**, and as long as the leader is alive and fighting alongside them, their **morale** is 10 rather than 8.

Halflings typically live in villages, or **shires**, of 30 to 300 inhabitants. Each village is led by a **sheriff** (a fighter of level 2-7) and protected by a village guard of 5-20 militia (each with 2 Hit Dice).

Special Abilities: Halflings get a +1 bonus to attack rolls when using missile weapons and a +2 bonus to Armor Class when fighting larger creatures.
Terrain: Hill, Open.

Harpy.biography:
Harpies are monstrous creatures with the lower body of a giant eagle and the upper body of a hideous woman. Their most dangerous ability is their **mesmerizing song**, which can charm anyone who hears it. Any creature hearing their song must make a saving throw vs. spells or become charmed. If a creature successfully makes the saving throw, they are immune to all harpy songs for the duration of the encounter.

Harpies prefer to live in secluded areas near places with steady human traffic, such as mountain passes or trade routes, where they can lure travelers to their doom. Once a location is no longer frequented by new victims, harpies will move to a new location and repeat the cycle.

Terrain: Hill, Mountain.
Load: 1,000 cn at full speed, 2,000 cn at half speed.

Haunt, Banshee*.biography:
The Banshee is a tormented undead soul that haunts desolate moors, forests, and dungeons. It is a guardian of its domain and may even protect certain creatures such as sprites or pixies, driving away intruders with its terrifying wails.

Undead Nature: The Banshee is an undead creature, immune to sleep, charm, and mind-affecting spells. It can only be harmed by +2 or better magical weapons and is immune to all spells except those that specifically affect evil beings.

Ectoplasmic Net: The Banshee exudes spectral tendrils that slowly form a 10' radius net. After 3 rounds, this net solidifies. Any living creature caught in the net must make a saving throw vs. spells or be pulled into the Ethereal Plane, where the Banshee can attack without interference from the physical world.

Gaze of Paralysis: The Banshee can lock eyes with a victim from 60' away. The target must make a saving throw vs. spells or be paralyzed for 2d4 rounds.

Aging Touch: If the Banshee touches a victim, it inflicts 1d4 × 10 years of unnatural aging. This aging effect permanently reduces 1 Constitution point per 10 years aged, and can only be undone by a potion of longevity or a wish spell.

Wail of Death: The Banshee can unleash a piercing wail three times per day. All creatures within 60' must make a saving throw vs. death ray or die instantly. The Banshee typically uses one wail at a distance to scare off intruders; NPCs and monsters hearing the wail must make a morale check at a +4 penalty. If avoided, the Banshee will not pursue.

Escape to the Ethereal Plane: When seriously threatened, the Banshee can shift to the Ethereal Plane up to 3 times per day and will remain there for 1d8 days before returning.

Clerical Turning Resistance: If a cleric attempts to turn a Banshee and gets a "D" result, the Banshee may make a saving throw vs. spells to resist destruction.

Treasure: The Banshee guards the wealth of past victims, stored somewhere within its haunted domain.

Terrain: Ruins, Moors, Deep Forests.

Haunt, Poltergeist*.biography:
The Poltergeist is an invisible haunt that exists to torment intruders. Unlike other haunts, it has no physical form and cannot be seen without magic. Its presence is known only by the eerie movement of objects and the sudden formation of an ectoplasmic net.

Undead Nature: The Poltergeist is immune to sleep, charm, and mind-affecting spells. It can only be harmed by +2 or better magical weapons and is immune to all spells except those affecting evil beings.

Invisibility: The Poltergeist is naturally invisible and can only be detected by magical means.

Ectoplasmic Net: A 10' radius spectral net forms around the Poltergeist over 3 rounds. Creatures inside must make a saving throw vs. spells or be pulled into the Ethereal Plane.

Gaze of Paralysis: The Poltergeist may gaze at a target within 60'. The victim must make a save vs. spells or be paralyzed for 2d4 rounds.

Telekinetic Assault: The Poltergeist can hurl two objects per round at opponents, dealing damage based on the object’s size. A saving throw vs. spells is required to avoid the aging effect.

Aging Attack: Each hit from a thrown object ages the victim by 10 years. A saving throw vs. spells negates this effect.

Escape to the Ethereal Plane: The Poltergeist may shift to the Ethereal Plane 3× per day and remain there for 1d8 days.

Turning Resistance: If a cleric attempts to turn it and rolls a "D", the Poltergeist may make a save vs. spells to resist destruction.

Terrain: Ruins, Haunted Buildings.

Headsman (10HD).biography:

Hippogriff.biography:
A hippogriff is a magical creature that has the foreparts and head of a giant eagle, and the hindquarters of a horse. These creatures are carnivorous, preferring to hunt herd animals. They are descended from a magical crossbreed of griffons and horses.

Hippogriffs are capable of carrying off man-sized or smaller prey and can be tamed to serve as mounts if raised from a young age. They usually nest in rocky crags but will fly wherever they need to hunt. They are natural enemies of pegasi, and when they encounter these creatures, hippogriffs must make a morale check or attack them despite their rider's commands.

Claw Damage: 1d6 per claw.
Bite Damage: 1d10.
Special Abilities: None.
Terrain: Mountain.
Load: 3,000 cn at full speed, 6,000 cn at half speed.

Hobgoblin.biography:
Hobgoblins are larger, meaner relatives of goblins, standing taller and bulkier. They often live underground in caves or dungeons, but regularly venture into rough wilderness or wastelands for hunting, without suffering any penalties in daylight.

A hobgoblin king, along with 1d4 bodyguards, leads the group in their lair. The king has 22 hit points and fights as a 5 HD monster with an additional +2 damage bonus. His bodyguards are as tough as 4 HD monsters, and each has 3d6 hit points. If the king is present and alive, hobgoblin morale increases to 10.

Weapon Damage: By weapon.
Terrain: Cavern, Hill, Mountain, Woods.

Horse, Riding.biography: A riding horse is a sturdy and reliable mount, capable of carrying a rider and light gear over long distances. It can travel at a moderate speed, suitable for general overland movement, and is well-suited for adventurers who need transportation between towns or through wilderness areas. The horse requires regular feeding, care, and rest but is versatile enough for most terrains. While it lacks the speed of a warhorse or the endurance of a draft horse, it is an ideal choice for basic travel​​.

Hydra (5HD).biography:
The hydra is a massive beast with a dragon-like body and multiple heads resembling snakes. Each hydra has between 5 and 12 heads, with one Hit Die and 8 hit points per head. The hydra attacks ferociously, using each of its heads every round. If a hydra loses a head, the damage it takes determines how many heads remain in the fight.

For every 8 points of damage taken, one of the hydra's heads is destroyed, reducing its ability to attack. For example, a hydra with 7 heads that takes 16 points of damage will lose two heads and attack with only five heads the following round.

Hydras can be found guarding treasures in remote and dangerous locations. While most hydras are found in swamps or other wilderness areas, variations of this creature exist with specialized abilities.

Terrain: Swamp.

Hydra, Flying (5HD).biography:
The flying hydra is a rare and terrifying version of the standard hydra, with enormous bat-like wings capable of carrying the creature over great distances. Unlike its land-based kin, the flying hydra can only attack with up to three heads at once while in flight. It often uses its agility to swoop down and attack with surprise.

Each head delivers powerful bites, and for every 8 points of damage, one head is destroyed, reducing the hydra's ability to attack. Flying hydras are most commonly found in mountainous regions, terrorizing anything that enters their territory.

Terrain: Mountain.

Hydra, Sea (5HD).biography:
The sea hydra is an aquatic version of its land-dwelling cousin, with fins in place of legs. Found in deep lakes or oceans, it is otherwise identical to the normal hydra. Each head attacks in the same way, using its powerful bites in combat, and for every 8 points of damage taken, one head is destroyed.

Though adapted for life underwater, sea hydras are no less dangerous and are often used to guard treasure hidden beneath the waves.

Terrain: Lake, Ocean.

Insect Swarm (2 HD).biography:
An insect swarm is a mass of small insects acting together as a single force. The swarm may fill a 10' x 10' x 30' area or larger, consisting of either crawling or flying insects, or a mix of both. These swarms may be drawn to light, strange smells, or may be defending a lair, such as a hive or nest.

The swarm does not make an attack roll, as it is an area effect attack that automatically hits. All armored characters and monsters with AC 5 or better take 2 points of damage per round. Unarmored characters or monsters with AC 6 or worse take 4 points of damage per round.

A victim who takes the time to swat at the insects (using a weapon or torch) instead of attacking or performing another action takes only 1 point of damage per round. Characters trying to swat with their hands or arms are ineffective.

If a swarm is attacked, it will relentlessly pursue its attacker. Victims can escape by disappearing from sight (such as with invisibility, moving around a corner, etc.) or by diving underwater, which kills all the insects after one round (normal damage applies during this round).

Terrain: Any (except Arctic)

Insect Swarm (4 HD).biography:
An insect swarm is a mass of small insects acting together as a single force. The swarm may fill a 10' x 10' x 30' area or larger, consisting of either crawling or flying insects, or a mix of both. These swarms may be drawn to light, strange smells, or may be defending a lair, such as a hive or nest.

The swarm does not make an attack roll, as it is an area effect attack that automatically hits. All armored characters and monsters with AC 5 or better take 2 points of damage per round. Unarmored characters or monsters with AC 6 or worse take 4 points of damage per round.

A victim who takes the time to swat at the insects (using a weapon or torch) instead of attacking or performing another action takes only 1 point of damage per round. Characters trying to swat with their hands or arms are ineffective.

If a swarm is attacked, it will relentlessly pursue its attacker. Victims can escape by disappearing from sight (such as with invisibility, moving around a corner, etc.) or by diving underwater, which kills all the insects after one round (normal damage applies during this round).

Terrain: Any (except Arctic)

Kobold.biography:
Kobolds are small, doglike humanoids with scaly, rust-brown skin and no hair. They live in underground tunnels and prefer to fight using ambush tactics. Their infravision extends up to 90 feet, allowing them to navigate in darkness with ease.

Kobolds organize into clans of 10 to 60 members. Each lair is ruled by a chieftain with 9 hit points who fights as a 2 HD monster. The chieftain is protected by 1d6 bodyguards (6 HP each, fighting as 1+1 HD monsters). As long as the chieftain is alive, the kobolds in the lair have increased morale (8 instead of 6).

These creatures have an intense hatred for gnomes and attack them on sight. Some kobolds possess magical talent, with spellcasters existing among their ranks.

Terrain: Cavern, Hill, Mountain, Wood.

Kryst*.biography:
Kryst are sentient beings composed entirely of crystalline rock, each appearing as a cluster of twelve gleaming golden crystal spikes radiating from a central core. Native to the elemental plane of Earth, they exude a distinctive, angular beauty.

They are immune to poison, standard weapons, all 1st and 2nd level spells, and any attack derived from air. A kryst can detect invisible creatures at will and is capable of casting detect magic, dispel magic, haste, or an 'air to earth' spell—similar to a magic-user's dissolve spell that transforms air into earth—three times per day, all as if cast by a 9th level magic-user. They communicate telepathically over a range of 120 feet or, if mental contact proves adverse, via written messages.

In combat, a kryst ram its foes with its crystal spikes, launching up to three attacks per round. Each spike functions as a natural weapon.

Beyond the battlefield, the kryst maintain a widespread and intricate society within their own realms, coexisting peacefully with earth elementals. They welcome visitors and eagerly seek new knowledge, yet they wage an unending war against the hordes and strive to unite other creatures against them. They are also known to oppose the hydrax—though encounters are rare—and harbor a deep-seated fear of water-based creatures and attacks.

Terrain: Plane of Earth

Reverse Spell: The reverse, *Slow*, either cancels *Haste* or reduces the target’s movement and attack speed by half. Each affected creature may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid *Slow*.

Example: After casting the spell, a magic-user can see a glowing door (locked by magic) and a glowing potion. A magical wand inside a treasure chest would not be visible as the chest hides its glow.

G6AhOk6vLWuGvKdL.description:
Magic-Users harness arcane energy through intense study and careful memorization of spells recorded in their spellbooks. Unlike Clerics, who receive divine magic, Magic-Users must prepare spells in advance by studying their books each day. Once a spell is cast, it is erased from memory until re-memorized.

Magic-Users have a limited selection of spells they can prepare per day, increasing as they gain levels. Their spells range from minor utilities such as Read Magic to devastating attacks like Fireball and reality-warping incantations at higher levels​.

Because of their reliance on spellbooks, Magic-Users must protect and expand their libraries, seeking out lost tomes, scrolls, and ancient knowledge to improve their magical repertoire.

Lava Ooze.biography:
This creature is a formless mass of searing, molten rock that resembles either a stagnant puddle or a streaming ribbon, spanning roughly 10' x 10'. It typically inhabits areas near active volcanoes or other regions marked by extreme heat, and although it originates from the Prime Plane, it can also thrive on the elemental plane of Fire.

The lava ooze is exceptionally fluid, capable of squeezing through even the narrowest crevices, and it detects vibrations within a 60' radius. In combat, it projects up to three pseudopods per round that can reach targets up to 15' away. Each pseudopod strike deals 4d6 points of damage and leaves a burning layer of lava on the target, which then inflicts an additional 3d6 points of heat damage per round for [/r 1d4 #rounds]. While multiple strikes on the same foe do not increase the per-round heat damage, their durations do stack.

This mindless ooze relentlessly attacks until it is destroyed. It is immune to both natural and magical fire as well as to all mind-affecting attacks (such as charm or ESP), but it takes double damage from cold-based assaults.

Terrain: Mountain (volcanic)

Lesser Phoenix*.biography:
Hailing from the elemental plane of Fire, the Lesser Phoenix appears as a striking red-orange eagle enveloped in fierce flames. On the Prime Plane, it’s an uncommon visitor, capable of thriving in any climate yet steadfastly avoiding underground lairs.

This creature remains peaceful unless provoked, resisting all forms of fire, charm, and hold spells, as well as attacks from weapons below a +3 enchantment. In combat, it employs its blazing claws and beak, while its fiery aura scorches foes within a 10' radius, inflicting [[/r 3d6 #Fire damage per round]], undeterred by conventional fire protections due to the unique nature of phoenix flame.

When vanquished, the Lesser Phoenix vanishes in a dramatic 20' radius explosion, unleashing [[/r 1d10*5 #Explosion damage]] (save vs. dragon breath for half, bypassing fire defenses). Lich, Cleric (21HD)*.biography:
A lich is a powerful undead monster of magical origin from the game. It appears as a skeleton clad in fine garments and was once an evil, chaotic cleric of level 21 (levels often range from 27 to 36). Retaining its spellcasting prowess from life, this lich remains an extremely dangerous adversary.

It is not typically encountered wandering, but is found in or near a well-defended lair such as a dungeon, catacomb, tomb, or necropolis ("city of the dead"). The mere sight of a lich instills terror in all characters below 5th level (no saving throw applies), while its touch inflicts 1d10 points of damage and may paralyze a target for 1d100 days (saving throw applies, and the paralysis is magically dispellable).

Prior to any encounter, the game master should carefully select spells for the lich given its formidable intelligence. Although its morale is listed as 10, a lich will flee if in actual danger.

Liches are undead and can be turned (though not destroyed) by clerics. They are immune to charm, sleep, feeblemind, polymorph, cold, lightning, and death spells, and can be harmed only by magical weapons. Additionally, they are immune to all spells of less than 4th level.

Outside its lair, a lich carries 1d4+1 powerful magical items for emergencies, while within its lair it possesses 4d8 additional temporary magical items (or more). A clerical lich typically has 3d4 types of other undead nearby, acting as servants – a full lair of each type (maximum number appearing) is usually present.

Either type of lich can summon other powerful undead for aid. To do so, the lich concentrates and the summoned creature(s) arrive 1d100 rounds later based on their distance. Summoning can be performed as often as desired, but each creature type will respond only once per day. To determine which creature is summoned, roll 1d20:
Roll 1-5: Spectre (2d4)
Roll 6-9: Vampire (1d6)
Roll 10-12: Phantom, Shade (1d3)
Roll 13-15: Haunt, Ghost (1d2 Chaotic)
Roll 16: Haunt, Poltergeist (1d2)
Roll 17: Spirit, Druj
Roll 18: Spirit, Revenant
Roll 19: Nightshade (any 1)
Roll 20: Undead Beholder

Roll [[/r 2d6 #Turn Undead]] for entries with numbers.

Wight--1197TTDDDDDDD+D+D+D+D+
Wraith----1197TTDDDDDDD+D+D+D+
Mummy------1197TTDDDDDDD+D+D+
Spectre--------1197TTDDDDDDD+D+

Lich--------------------1197TTTT

Notes:

  • 7, 9, or 11: Number needed to turn successfully.
  • T: Automatic turn; turns 2d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D: Automatic destroy; destroys 2d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D+: Automatic destroy; destroys 3d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D#: Automatic destroy; destroys 4d6 Hit Dice of undead.

Clerics have the divine power to repel or even destroy certain undead creatures, such as skeletons, zombies, and more powerful types. This ability is known as Turn Undead. When encountering these undead beings, the cleric can choose to either engage them in combat with weapons or spells, or attempt to turn them.

To turn undead, the cleric simply announces the intention to do so to the Dungeon Master. No holy symbol or other item is needed unless the DM specifies otherwise. The success of this attempt depends on the cleric’s level and the type of undead faced, as indicated on the Turning Undead table.

If the cleric succeeds, one or more undead creatures will flee or be destroyed immediately, depending on the result. However, a failed attempt means that particular undead creature cannot be turned by the cleric again during the same encounter. Multiple attempts are allowed in future encounters.

Should the attempt succeed, the Dungeon Master rolls to determine how many Hit Dice worth of undead are turned. At least one undead creature will always be affected. A turned undead creature will retreat as far as possible, but it has not been destroyed and may return after some time.
kvmI8fDyFzKzoPMF.name: Turn Undead

Lich, Cleric (25HD)*.biography:
A lich is a powerful undead monster of magical origin from the game. It appears as a skeleton clad in fine garments and was once an evil, chaotic cleric of level 25 (levels often range from 27 to 36). Retaining its spellcasting prowess from life, this lich remains an extremely dangerous adversary.

It is not typically encountered wandering, but is found in or near a well-defended lair such as a dungeon, catacomb, tomb, or necropolis ("city of the dead"). The mere sight of a lich instills terror in all characters below 5th level (no saving throw applies), while its touch inflicts 1d10 points of damage and may paralyze a target for 1d100 days (saving throw applies, and the paralysis is magically dispellable).

Prior to any encounter, the game master should carefully select spells for the lich given its formidable intelligence. Although its morale is listed as 10, a lich will flee if in actual danger.

Liches are undead and can be turned (though not destroyed) by clerics. They are immune to charm, sleep, feeblemind, polymorph, cold, lightning, and death spells, and can be harmed only by magical weapons. Additionally, they are immune to all spells of less than 4th level.

Outside its lair, a lich carries 1d4+1 powerful magical items for emergencies, while within its lair it possesses 4d8 additional temporary magical items (or more). A clerical lich typically has 3d4 types of other undead nearby, acting as servants – a full lair of each type (maximum number appearing) is usually present.

Either type of lich can summon other powerful undead for aid. To do so, the lich concentrates and the summoned creature(s) arrive 1d100 rounds later based on their distance. Roll 1-5: Spectre (2d4)
Roll 6-9: Vampire (1d6)

Roll 16: Haunt, Poltergeist (1d2)
Roll 17: Spirit, Druj

Roll 19: Nightshade (any 1)
Roll 20: Undead Beholder

Roll [[/r 2d6 #Turn Undead]] for entries with numbers.

Lich--------------------1197TTTT

Notes:

  • 7, 9, or 11: Number needed to turn successfully.
  • T: Automatic turn; turns 2d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D: Automatic destroy; destroys 2d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D+: Automatic destroy; destroys 3d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D#: Automatic destroy; destroys 4d6 Hit Dice of undead.

Clerics have the divine power to repel or even destroy certain undead creatures, such as skeletons, zombies, and more powerful types. This ability is known as Turn Undead. When encountering these undead beings, the cleric can choose to either engage them in combat with weapons or spells, or attempt to turn them.

To turn undead, the cleric simply announces the intention to do so to the Dungeon Master. No holy symbol or other item is needed unless the DM specifies otherwise. The success of this attempt depends on the cleric’s level and the type of undead faced, as indicated on the Turning Undead table.

If the cleric succeeds, one or more undead creatures will flee or be destroyed immediately, depending on the result. However, a failed attempt means that particular undead creature cannot be turned by the cleric again during the same encounter. Multiple attempts are allowed in future encounters.

Should the attempt succeed, the Dungeon Master rolls to determine how many Hit Dice worth of undead are turned. At least one undead creature will always be affected. A turned undead creature will retreat as far as possible, but it has not been destroyed and may return after some time.

A lich is a powerful undead monster of magical origin from the game. It appears as a skeleton clad in fine garments and was once an evil, chaotic cleric of level 29 (levels often range from 27 to 36). Retaining its spellcasting prowess from life, this lich remains an extremely dangerous adversary.

It is not typically encountered wandering, but is found in or near a well-defended lair such as a dungeon, catacomb, tomb, or necropolis ("city of the dead"). The mere sight of a lich instills terror in all characters below 5th level (no saving throw applies), while its touch inflicts 1d10 points of damage and may paralyze a target for 1d100 days (saving throw applies, and the paralysis is magically dispellable).

Prior to any encounter, the game master should carefully select spells for the lich given its formidable intelligence. Although its morale is listed as 10, a lich will flee if in actual danger.

Liches are undead and can be turned (though not destroyed) by clerics. They are immune to charm, sleep, feeblemind, polymorph, cold, lightning, and death spells, and can be harmed only by magical weapons. Additionally, they are immune to all spells of less than 4th level.

Outside its lair, a lich carries 1d4+1 powerful magical items for emergencies, while within its lair it possesses 4d8 additional temporary magical items (or more). Lich, Cleric (34HD)*.biography:
A lich is a powerful undead monster of magical origin from the game. It appears as a skeleton clad in fine garments and was once an evil, chaotic cleric of level 34 (levels often range from 27 to 36). Retaining its spellcasting prowess from life, this lich remains an extremely dangerous adversary.

It is not typically encountered wandering, but is found in or near a well-defended lair such as a dungeon, catacomb, tomb, or necropolis ("city of the dead"). The mere sight of a lich instills terror in all characters below 5th level (no saving throw applies), while its touch inflicts 1d10 points of damage and may paralyze a target for 1d100 days (saving throw applies, and the paralysis is magically dispellable).

Prior to any encounter, the game master should carefully select spells for the lich given its formidable intelligence. Although its morale is listed as 10, a lich will flee if in actual danger.

Liches are undead and can be turned (though not destroyed) by clerics. They are immune to charm, sleep, feeblemind, polymorph, cold, lightning, and death spells, and can be harmed only by magical weapons. Additionally, they are immune to all spells of less than 4th level.

Outside its lair, a lich carries 1d4+1 powerful magical items for emergencies, while within its lair it possesses 4d8 additional temporary magical items (or more). A clerical lich typically has 3d4 types of other undead nearby, acting as servants – a full lair of each type (maximum number appearing) is usually present.

Either type of lich can summon other powerful undead for aid. To do so, the lich concentrates and the summoned creature(s) arrive 1d100 rounds later based on their distance. Summoning can be performed as often as desired, but each creature type will respond only once per day. To determine which creature is summoned, roll 1d20:
Roll 1-5: Spectre (2d4)
Roll 6-9: Vampire (1d6)
Roll 10-12: Phantom, Shade (1d3)
Roll 13-15: Haunt, Ghost (1d2 Chaotic)
Roll 16: Haunt, Poltergeist (1d2)
Roll 17: Spirit, Druj
Roll 18: Spirit, Revenant
Roll 19: Nightshade (any 1)
Roll 20: Undead Beholder

Terrain: Ruins

Lich, Magic-User (21HD)*.biography:
A magic-user lich is a fearsome undead creature of arcane origin from the game. It appears as a skeleton clad in fine garments and was once a powerful, chaotic magic-user of level 21 (levels often range from 27 to 36). Retaining its arcane might from life, this lich poses a formidable threat to any who dare challenge it.

It is not typically encountered wandering, but is usually found in or near a well-defended lair such as a dungeon, catacomb, tomb, or necropolis ("city of the dead"). Its mere presence instills dread, as its touch inflicts 1d10 points of damage and may paralyze a target for 1d100 days (a saving throw applies, and the paralysis is magically dispellable).

Before any encounter, the game master should carefully select spells for the lich, considering its exceptional intelligence. Although its morale is listed as 10, a lich will flee if confronted with overwhelming danger.

Magic-user liches are undead and can be turned (though not destroyed) by clerics. They are immune to charm, sleep, feeblemind, polymorph, cold, lightning, and death spells, and can be harmed only by magical weapons. Additionally, they are immune to all spells below 4th level.

In addition, a magic-user lich normally has 1d2 spells of permanent nature—most often detect invisible or fly. It also carries treasure comprising coins, gems, and jewelry as specified for Treasure Type H in Chapter 16 (with a 90% chance for each type).

Terrain: Ruins

25m1OnivKJJKH2RW.description:
Upon reaching 9th level, a Magic-User may choose to build a tower, establishing themselves as a land-owning wizard. Unlike Fighters or Clerics, a Magic-User does not need permission from the local ruler to construct a stronghold, as rulers generally avoid antagonizing powerful wizards​.

Attracting Apprentices

Once a tower is built, the Magic-User will attract 1d6 apprentices, all Magic-Users of levels 1–3. These apprentices seek training, and while they are loyal, they will not sacrifice themselves for their master. The DM determines their names, backgrounds, and personalities​.

Stronghold and Dungeon Construction

A wizard's tower may include a dungeon beneath or near it. Some wizards construct dungeons as secure laboratories, while others leave an opening, attracting wandering monsters that take up residence. Some wizards encourage this, using monsters for research, spell experimentation, or personal defense​. However, monster-infested dungeons often cause conflict with local communities and attract adventurers seeking treasure.

Alternative to a Tower: Becoming a Magist

Instead of building a tower, a Name-level Magic-User may seek employment as a Magist in an existing stronghold. A Magist serves a ruler as an advisor on magical matters, handles magical needs, and is well-compensated—typically at least 3,000 gp per month. However, this requires the Magic-User to swear an oath of fealty to the ruler​.

Would you like additional details, such as construction costs or typical tower layouts?
25m1OnivKJJKH2RW.name: Establish Tower

S9QGVlBRn4Md8rcs.description:
At 9th level, a Magic-User can begin crafting magic items, but only items usable by Magic-Users. The process involves:

  • Gathering rare materials related to the item's magic (e.g., dragon scales for fire resistance)
  • Spending time and gold to craft and enchant the item
  • A base cost of 500 gp per spell level for items that duplicate spell effects
  • A 15% minimum chance of failure, determined at the end of the process​

Scrolls and potions are the easiest to create, while more powerful items require months of work and possibly special rituals. The DM may set additional requirements for powerful magic items, such as needing a specific location or celestial alignment​.
S9QGVlBRn4Md8rcs.name: Create Magic Items

cRfkrRzLX4wbXBJl.description:
Magic-Users harness arcane energy through intense study and careful memorization of spells recorded in their spellbooks. Unlike Clerics, who receive divine magic, Magic-Users must prepare spells in advance by studying their books each day. Once a spell is cast, it is erased from memory until re-memorized.

Magic-Users have a limited selection of spells they can prepare per day, increasing as they gain levels. Their spells range from minor utilities such as Read Magic to devastating attacks like Fireball and reality-warping incantations at higher levels​.

Because of their reliance on spellbooks, Magic-Users must protect and expand their libraries, seeking out lost tomes, scrolls, and ancient knowledge to improve their magical repertoire.
cRfkrRzLX4wbXBJl.name: Arcane Spellcasting

Lich, Magic-User (22HD)*.biography:
A magic-user lich is a fearsome undead creature of arcane origin from the game. It appears as a skeleton clad in fine garments and was once a powerful, chaotic magic-user of level 22 (levels often range from 27 to 36). Retaining its arcane might from life, this lich poses a formidable threat to any who dare challenge it.

It is not typically encountered wandering, but is usually found in or near a well-defended lair such as a dungeon, catacomb, tomb, or necropolis ("city of the dead"). Its mere presence instills dread, as its touch inflicts 1d10 points of damage and may paralyze a target for 1d100 days (a saving throw applies, and the paralysis is magically dispellable).

Before any encounter, the game master should carefully select spells for the lich, considering its exceptional intelligence. Although its morale is listed as 10, a lich will flee if confronted with overwhelming danger.

Magic-user liches are undead and can be turned (though not destroyed) by clerics. They are immune to charm, sleep, feeblemind, polymorph, cold, lightning, and death spells, and can be harmed only by magical weapons. Additionally, they are immune to all spells below 4th level.

In addition, a magic-user lich normally has 1d2 spells of permanent nature—most often detect invisible or fly. It also carries treasure comprising coins, gems, and jewelry as specified for Treasure Type H in Chapter 16 (with a 90% chance for each type).

Terrain: Ruins

The target number to save is determined by the character's class and level, as found on the saving throw table​​.
8zKMHqmN3UxUYSkY.name: Magic Wand

HSxhs4z5zqdBGLkI.description:
At 9th level, a Magic-User can begin crafting magic items, but only items usable by Magic-Users. The process involves:

  • Gathering rare materials related to the item's magic (e.g., dragon scales for fire resistance)
  • Spending time and gold to craft and enchant the item
  • A base cost of 500 gp per spell level for items that duplicate spell effects
  • A 15% minimum chance of failure, determined at the end of the process​

Scrolls and potions are the easiest to create, while more powerful items require months of work and possibly special rituals. The DM may set additional requirements for powerful magic items, such as needing a specific location or celestial alignment​.
HSxhs4z5zqdBGLkI.name: Create Magic Items

OJ8iGgVa9sn9VLTH.description:
Upon reaching 9th level, a Magic-User may choose to build a tower, establishing themselves as a land-owning wizard. Unlike Fighters or Clerics, a Magic-User does not need permission from the local ruler to construct a stronghold, as rulers generally avoid antagonizing powerful wizards​.

Attracting Apprentices

Once a tower is built, the Magic-User will attract 1d6 apprentices, all Magic-Users of levels 1–3. These apprentices seek training, and while they are loyal, they will not sacrifice themselves for their master. The DM determines their names, backgrounds, and personalities​.

Stronghold and Dungeon Construction

A wizard's tower may include a dungeon beneath or near it. Some wizards construct dungeons as secure laboratories, while others leave an opening, attracting wandering monsters that take up residence. Some wizards encourage this, using monsters for research, spell experimentation, or personal defense​. However, monster-infested dungeons often cause conflict with local communities and attract adventurers seeking treasure.

Alternative to a Tower: Becoming a Magist

Instead of building a tower, a Name-level Magic-User may seek employment as a Magist in an existing stronghold. A Magist serves a ruler as an advisor on magical matters, handles magical needs, and is well-compensated—typically at least 3,000 gp per month. However, this requires the Magic-User to swear an oath of fealty to the ruler​.

Would you like additional details, such as construction costs or typical tower layouts?
OJ8iGgVa9sn9VLTH.name: Establish Tower

hiwcxG3sRCzCeC0K.description:
Magic-Users harness arcane energy through intense study and careful memorization of spells recorded in their spellbooks. Unlike Clerics, who receive divine magic, Magic-Users must prepare spells in advance by studying their books each day. Once a spell is cast, it is erased from memory until re-memorized.

Magic-Users have a limited selection of spells they can prepare per day, increasing as they gain levels. Their spells range from minor utilities such as Read Magic to devastating attacks like Fireball and reality-warping incantations at higher levels​.

Because of their reliance on spellbooks, Magic-Users must protect and expand their libraries, seeking out lost tomes, scrolls, and ancient knowledge to improve their magical repertoire.
hiwcxG3sRCzCeC0K.name: Arcane Spellcasting

Some wizards encourage this, using monsters for research, spell experimentation, or personal defense​. However, monster-infested dungeons often cause conflict with local communities and attract adventurers seeking treasure.

Alternative to a Tower: Becoming a Magist

Instead of building a tower, a Name-level Magic-User may seek employment as a Magist in an existing stronghold. A Magist serves a ruler as an advisor on magical matters, handles magical needs, and is well-compensated—typically at least 3,000 gp per month. However, this requires the Magic-User to swear an oath of fealty to the ruler​.
