badKZEMDlxG7Rj5K.description:
Magic-Users harness arcane energy through intense study and careful memorization of spells recorded in their spellbooks. Unlike Clerics, who receive divine magic, Magic-Users must prepare spells in advance by studying their books each day. Once a spell is cast, it is erased from memory until re-memorized.

Magic-Users have a limited selection of spells they can prepare per day, increasing as they gain levels. Their spells range from minor utilities such as Read Magic to devastating attacks like Fireball and reality-warping incantations at higher levels​.

Because of their reliance on spellbooks, Magic-Users must protect and expand their libraries, seeking out lost tomes, scrolls, and ancient knowledge to improve their magical repertoire.
badKZEMDlxG7Rj5K.name: Arcane Spellcasting

cS857nxyjBcB0nnZ.description:
At 9th level, a Magic-User can begin crafting magic items, but only items usable by Magic-Users. The process involves:

  • Gathering rare materials related to the item's magic (e.g., dragon scales for fire resistance)
  • Spending time and gold to craft and enchant the item
  • A base cost of 500 gp per spell level for items that duplicate spell effects
  • A 15% minimum chance of failure, determined at the end of the process​

Scrolls and potions are the easiest to create, while more powerful items require months of work and possibly special rituals. The DM may set additional requirements for powerful magic items, such as needing a specific location or celestial alignment​.
cS857nxyjBcB0nnZ.name: Create Magic Items

hsYzjudIeRIxOvso.description: This spell allows the lich to detect invisible creatures within a 60-foot radius.
hsYzjudIeRIxOvso.name: Detect Invisible

jVJgdudA5MiotiKB.description: The Death Ray or Poison saving throw is a roll made by a character to resist deadly effects like instant death or paralysis from poisons, spells, or traps. The player rolls a d20 and compares it to their class- and level-specific target number on the saving throw table; success means avoiding or mitigating the harm. A failed roll often results in death (for poison) or other severe consequences, though optional rules may instead inflict substantial damage​​​.
jVJgdudA5MiotiKB.name: Death Ray or Poison

mrHqugYVfdAapFFg.description: The saving throw against Breath Weapons is used to resist or mitigate the effects of a wide range of powerful exhaled attacks, not limited to dragons. This includes attacks like a dragon’s fiery or icy breath, a gorgon's petrifying breath, or a chimera's elemental breath. Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. The target number for the saving throw is determined by the character’s class and level.
mrHqugYVfdAapFFg.name: Dragon Breath

rY0v1ZzeV9EfTtEY.description: Magic-Users can utilize various magical items, such as wands, staves, and scrolls, that are typically unavailable to non-spellcasting classes. This ability allows them to activate magical effects stored within these items.
rY0v1ZzeV9EfTtEY.name: Use Magic Items

rZgDGMajNeKanN0S.description: The saving throw for Spells or Magic Staff includes resistance against magical effects cast by rods, staves, wands, or through spells. A successful save, rolled on a d20, often reduces or negates the spell's effects entirely. This saving throw is applicable to numerous magical attacks, such as charm spells, fireballs, or paralysis effects, and covers damage, control, or debilitating conditions caused by magical devices or spellcasters. The target number for success is based on the character's class and level.
rZgDGMajNeKanN0S.name: Spells or Magic Staff

xF8suWhXhyXIIwcf.description:
A Magic-User can attempt to create a new spell, but it must be of a level they can cast. The process requires:

  • 1,000 gp per spell level
  • Two weeks of research per spell level
  • Rare components, often requiring an adventure to obtain
  • A fully stocked laboratory or library

The chance of success depends on the Magic-User's Intelligence score and level, with modifications for spell difficulty​. If a research attempt fails, the process must be restarted, but each failure grants a +5% cumulative bonus to future attempts.

A Magic-User typically does not have a sufficient library for advanced research until 18th level, or at least 9th level if they have collected extensive magical tomes​. While research is technically possible at any level, low-level characters will likely struggle to meet the requirements.
xF8suWhXhyXIIwcf.name: Spell Research

Lich, Magic-User (26HD)*.biography:
A magic-user lich is a fearsome undead creature of arcane origin from the game. It appears as a skeleton clad in fine garments and was once a powerful, chaotic magic-user of level 26 (levels often range from 27 to 36). Retaining its arcane might from life, this lich poses a formidable threat to any who dare challenge it.

It is not typically encountered wandering, but is usually found in or near a well-defended lair such as a dungeon, catacomb, tomb, or necropolis ("city of the dead"). Its mere presence instills dread, as its touch inflicts 1d10 points of damage and may paralyze a target for 1d100 days (a saving throw applies, and the paralysis is magically dispellable).

Before any encounter, the game master should carefully select spells for the lich, considering its exceptional intelligence. Although its morale is listed as 10, a lich will flee if confronted with overwhelming danger.

Magic-user liches are undead and can be turned (though not destroyed) by clerics. They are immune to charm, sleep, feeblemind, polymorph, cold, lightning, and death spells, and can be harmed only by magical weapons. Additionally, they are immune to all spells below 4th level.

In addition, a magic-user lich normally has 1d2 spells of permanent nature—most often detect invisible or fly. It also carries treasure comprising coins, gems, and jewelry as specified for Treasure Type H in Chapter 16 (with a 90% chance for each type).

A successful save, rolled on a d20, often reduces or negates the spell's effects entirely. This saving throw is applicable to numerous magical attacks, such as charm spells, fireballs, or paralysis effects, and covers damage, control, or debilitating conditions caused by magical devices or spellcasters. The target number for success is based on the character's class and level.
wO96nhpAYaCONYic.name: Spells or Magic Staff

yi3VPahARGEzQr7W.description:
At 9th level, a Magic-User can begin crafting magic items, but only items usable by Magic-Users. The process involves:

  • Gathering rare materials related to the item's magic (e.g., dragon scales for fire resistance)
  • Spending time and gold to craft and enchant the item
  • A base cost of 500 gp per spell level for items that duplicate spell effects
  • A 15% minimum chance of failure, determined at the end of the process​

Scrolls and potions are the easiest to create, while more powerful items require months of work and possibly special rituals. The DM may set additional requirements for powerful magic items, such as needing a specific location or celestial alignment​.
yi3VPahARGEzQr7W.name: Create Magic Items

zYze1nxU9RJ1Cwji.description:
Upon reaching 9th level, a Magic-User may choose to build a tower, establishing themselves as a land-owning wizard. Unlike Fighters or Clerics, a Magic-User does not need permission from the local ruler to construct a stronghold, as rulers generally avoid antagonizing powerful wizards​.

Attracting Apprentices

Once a tower is built, the Magic-User will attract 1d6 apprentices, all Magic-Users of levels 1–3. These apprentices seek training, and while they are loyal, they will not sacrifice themselves for their master. The DM determines their names, backgrounds, and personalities​.

Stronghold and Dungeon Construction

A wizard's tower may include a dungeon beneath or near it. Some wizards construct dungeons as secure laboratories, while others leave an opening, attracting wandering monsters that take up residence. Some wizards encourage this, using monsters for research, spell experimentation, or personal defense​. However, monster-infested dungeons often cause conflict with local communities and attract adventurers seeking treasure.

Alternative to a Tower: Becoming a Magist

Instead of building a tower, a Name-level Magic-User may seek employment as a Magist in an existing stronghold. A Magist serves a ruler as an advisor on magical matters, handles magical needs, and is well-compensated—typically at least 3,000 gp per month. However, this requires the Magic-User to swear an oath of fealty to the ruler​.

Would you like additional details, such as construction costs or typical tower layouts?
zYze1nxU9RJ1Cwji.name: Establish Tower

Lich, Magic-User (29HD)*.biography:
A magic-user lich is a fearsome undead creature of arcane origin from the game. It appears as a skeleton clad in fine garments and was once a powerful, chaotic magic-user of level 29 (levels often range from 27 to 36). Retaining its arcane might from life, this lich poses a formidable threat to any who dare challenge it.

It is not typically encountered wandering, but is usually found in or near a well-defended lair such as a dungeon, catacomb, tomb, or necropolis ("city of the dead"). Its mere presence instills dread, as its touch inflicts 1d10 points of damage and may paralyze a target for 1d100 days (a saving throw applies, and the paralysis is magically dispellable).

Before any encounter, the game master should carefully select spells for the lich, considering its exceptional intelligence. Although its morale is listed as 10, a lich will flee if confronted with overwhelming danger.

Magic-user liches are undead and can be turned (though not destroyed) by clerics. They are immune to charm, sleep, feeblemind, polymorph, cold, lightning, and death spells, and can be harmed only by magical weapons. Additionally, they are immune to all spells below 4th level.

In addition, a magic-user lich normally has 1d2 spells of permanent nature—most often detect invisible or fly. It also carries treasure comprising coins, gems, and jewelry as specified for Treasure Type H in Chapter 16 (with a 90% chance for each type).

Terrain: Ruins

19LZhCjtt8AGMcNq.description: The saving throw against "Stone or Paralysis" protects a character from attacks or effects that could freeze them in place (paralysis) or turn them into stone. If the saving throw is failed, the character becomes immobilized or petrified, depending on the effect. Paralysis leaves a character aware but unable to act, while petrification turns the character and their carried equipment into a stone statue. The duration or permanence of these effects is specified by the source, and successful saving throws avoid them entirely​​​.
19LZhCjtt8AGMcNq.name: Turn to Stone or Paralysis

6c3bRl0AJwUVrYU8.description: The saving throw against Breath Weapons is used to resist or mitigate the effects of a wide range of powerful exhaled attacks, not limited to dragons. This includes attacks like a dragon’s fiery or icy breath, a gorgon's petrifying breath, or a chimera's elemental breath. Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. The target number for the saving throw is determined by the character’s class and level.
6c3bRl0AJwUVrYU8.name: Dragon Breath

dB5lXpMdxVSbAuK9.description:
A Magic-User can attempt to create a new spell, but it must be of a level they can cast. The process requires:

  • 1,000 gp per spell level
  • Two weeks of research per spell level
  • Rare components, often requiring an adventure to obtain
  • A fully stocked laboratory or library

The chance of success depends on the Magic-User's Intelligence score and level, with modifications for spell difficulty​. If a research attempt fails, the process must be restarted, but each failure grants a +5% cumulative bonus to future attempts.

m12NyObIr151Hf7e.description:
A Magic-User can attempt to create a new spell, but it must be of a level they can cast. The process requires:

  • 1,000 gp per spell level
  • Two weeks of research per spell level
  • Rare components, often requiring an adventure to obtain
  • A fully stocked laboratory or library

The chance of success depends on the Magic-User's Intelligence score and level, with modifications for spell difficulty​. If a research attempt fails, the process must be restarted, but each failure grants a +5% cumulative bonus to future attempts.

A Magic-User typically does not have a sufficient library for advanced research until 18th level, or at least 9th level if they have collected extensive magical tomes​. While research is technically possible at any level, low-level characters will likely struggle to meet the requirements.

shWplcik72OoWysP.description:
At 9th level, a Magic-User can begin crafting magic items, but only items usable by Magic-Users. The process involves:

  • Gathering rare materials related to the item's magic (e.g., dragon scales for fire resistance)
  • Spending time and gold to craft and enchant the item
  • A base cost of 500 gp per spell level for items that duplicate spell effects
  • A 15% minimum chance of failure, determined at the end of the process​

Scrolls and potions are the easiest to create, while more powerful items require months of work and possibly special rituals. The DM may set additional requirements for powerful magic items, such as needing a specific location or celestial alignment​.
shWplcik72OoWysP.name: Create Magic Items

xfoMNsoIVJU1ZP3g.description:
Magic-Users harness arcane energy through intense study and careful memorization of spells recorded in their spellbooks. Unlike Clerics, who receive divine magic, Magic-Users must prepare spells in advance by studying their books each day. Once a spell is cast, it is erased from memory until re-memorized.

Magic-Users have a limited selection of spells they can prepare per day, increasing as they gain levels. Their spells range from minor utilities such as Read Magic to devastating attacks like Fireball and reality-warping incantations at higher levels​.

Because of their reliance on spellbooks, Magic-Users must protect and expand their libraries, seeking out lost tomes, scrolls, and ancient knowledge to improve their magical repertoire.
xfoMNsoIVJU1ZP3g.name: Arcane Spellcasting

yyELVjtfYYX7bpyu.description: The saving throw against Breath Weapons is used to resist or mitigate the effects of a wide range of powerful exhaled attacks, not limited to dragons. This includes attacks like a dragon’s fiery or icy breath, a gorgon's petrifying breath, or a chimera's elemental breath. Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. The target number for the saving throw is determined by the character’s class and level.
yyELVjtfYYX7bpyu.name: Dragon Breath

Unlike Clerics, who receive divine magic, Magic-Users must prepare spells in advance by studying their books each day. Once a spell is cast, it is erased from memory until re-memorized.

Magic-Users have a limited selection of spells they can prepare per day, increasing as they gain levels. Their spells range from minor utilities such as Read Magic to devastating attacks like Fireball and reality-warping incantations at higher levels​.

Because of their reliance on spellbooks, Magic-Users must protect and expand their libraries, seeking out lost tomes, scrolls, and ancient knowledge to improve their magical repertoire.
OrDEulbgkLUp8aBS.name: Arcane Spellcasting

The target number for success is based on the character's class and level.

wL8cinLNg7n2yjxF.description:
A Magic-User can attempt to create a new spell, but it must be of a level they can cast. The process requires:

  • 1,000 gp per spell level
  • Two weeks of research per spell level
  • Rare components, often requiring an adventure to obtain
  • A fully stocked laboratory or library

The chance of success depends on the Magic-User's Intelligence score and level, with modifications for spell difficulty​. If a research attempt fails, the process must be restarted, but each failure grants a +5% cumulative bonus to future attempts.

A Magic-User typically does not have a sufficient library for advanced research until 18th level, or at least 9th level if they have collected extensive magical tomes​. While research is technically possible at any level, low-level characters will likely struggle to meet the requirements.
wL8cinLNg7n2yjxF.name: Spell Research

Lich, Magic-User (36HD)*.biography:
A magic-user lich is a fearsome undead creature of arcane origin from the game. It appears as a skeleton clad in fine garments and was once a powerful, chaotic magic-user of level 36 (levels often range from 27 to 36). Retaining its arcane might from life, this lich poses a formidable threat to any who dare challenge it.

It is not typically encountered wandering, but is usually found in or near a well-defended lair such as a dungeon, catacomb, tomb, or necropolis ("city of the dead"). Its mere presence instills dread, as its touch inflicts 1d10 points of damage and may paralyze a target for 1d100 days (a saving throw applies, and the paralysis is magically dispellable).

Before any encounter, the game master should carefully select spells for the lich, considering its exceptional intelligence. Although its morale is listed as 10, a lich will flee if confronted with overwhelming danger.

Magic-user liches are undead and can be turned (though not destroyed) by clerics. They are immune to charm, sleep, feeblemind, polymorph, cold, lightning, and death spells, and can be harmed only by magical weapons. Additionally, they are immune to all spells below 4th level.

In addition, a magic-user lich normally has 1d2 spells of permanent nature—most often detect invisible or fly. It also carries treasure comprising coins, gems, and jewelry as specified for Treasure Type H in Chapter 16 (with a 90% chance for each type).

Terrain: Ruins

P9478MbQlc3dD13v.description:
At 9th level, a Magic-User can begin crafting magic items, but only items usable by Magic-Users. The process involves:

  • Gathering rare materials related to the item's magic (e.g., dragon scales for fire resistance)
  • Spending time and gold to craft and enchant the item
  • A base cost of 500 gp per spell level for items that duplicate spell effects
  • A 15% minimum chance of failure, determined at the end of the process​

Scrolls and potions are the easiest to create, while more powerful items require months of work and possibly special rituals. The DM may set additional requirements for powerful magic items, such as needing a specific location or celestial alignment​.

YPIGCgDUO3e0ikBp.description:
Upon reaching 9th level, a Magic-User may choose to build a tower, establishing themselves as a land-owning wizard. Unlike Fighters or Clerics, a Magic-User does not need permission from the local ruler to construct a stronghold, as rulers generally avoid antagonizing powerful wizards​.

Attracting Apprentices

Once a tower is built, the Magic-User will attract 1d6 apprentices, all Magic-Users of levels 1–3. These apprentices seek training, and while they are loyal, they will not sacrifice themselves for their master. The DM determines their names, backgrounds, and personalities​.

Stronghold and Dungeon Construction

A wizard's tower may include a dungeon beneath or near it. Some wizards construct dungeons as secure laboratories, while others leave an opening, attracting wandering monsters that take up residence. Some wizards encourage this, using monsters for research, spell experimentation, or personal defense​. However, monster-infested dungeons often cause conflict with local communities and attract adventurers seeking treasure.

Alternative to a Tower: Becoming a Magist

Instead of building a tower, a Name-level Magic-User may seek employment as a Magist in an existing stronghold. A Magist serves a ruler as an advisor on magical matters, handles magical needs, and is well-compensated—typically at least 3,000 gp per month. However, this requires the Magic-User to swear an oath of fealty to the ruler​.

Would you like additional details, such as construction costs or typical tower layouts?
YPIGCgDUO3e0ikBp.name: Establish Tower

Lizard Man.biography:
Lizard Men thrive in swamps, rivers, lakes, and coastal caverns, their humanoid forms adorned with scaly hides, clawed hands, tails, and reptilian heads. Ranging from drab green or brown to vivid reds, blues, yellows, or greens, these water-dwelling tribes hunt relentlessly, often capturing humans and demihumans for feasts at their lairs.

Semi-intelligent, they wield spears or large clubs—treated as maces—with a +1 damage bonus from their formidable strength (e.g., [[/r 1d6+1 #Weapon damage]] for spear). One in ten speaks rudimentary Common, allowing tense negotiations—though hunger may override talk if food isn’t offered, driving them to dine on their interlocutors.

Living arduous lives, they roam in bands of [[/r 2d4 #Lizard Men wandering]] or lairs of [[/r 6d6 #Lizard Men in lair]], sometimes serving other races as warriors or scouts for sustenance. Neutral and pragmatic, they hoard modest treasures, valuing only what aids their survival (HD 2 + 1, XP 25).
Terrain: Cavern, River/Lake, Swamps

Lizard, Draco.biography:
The Draco lizard is a 6' long creature with wide flaps of skin between its legs. It uses these flaps to glide through the air, much like a flying squirrel. Dracos are commonly found above ground, though they may take refuge in caves during periods of extreme weather.

They are carnivores and are known to attack adventurers when provoked. Although they can glide for long distances, they cannot actually fly. Draco lizards are generally not tamed as mounts without special training and DM approval.

Terrain: Cavern, Desert, Woods.
Load: Giant lizards can carry 500 cn x their HD at full speed or 1,000 cn x their HD at half speed.
Barding Multiplier: x 3.

Lycanthrope, Devil Swine.biography:
Devil Swine are shape-changing lycanthropes, appearing either as massive swine or as obese humans. They freely change shapes at night but must remain in one form during daylight hours. Devil Swine are carnivorous, favoring human flesh, and often live near human settlements where they can hunt. They ambush their prey, and each Devil Swine can cast Charm Person up to three times per day, in either human or swine form. Victims must make a saving throw vs. spells with a -2 penalty; charmed humans become controlled minions, with 0-3 usually under a Devil Swine's control.

In animal form, Devil Swine can only be harmed by magical or silvered weapons and communicate with other swine. In human form, they can use any weapon, speak any known language, and are vulnerable to normal attacks.

Lycanthropy: Any human who loses more than half of their hit points to a Devil Swine’s gore or weapon attack becomes a Devil Swine within 2d12 days. The disease is fatal to demihumans and can only be cured by a cleric of 11th level or higher.

Terrain: Forests, swamps, or areas near human settlements

Lycanthrope, Werefox.biography:
Werefoxes are intelligent and nimble lycanthropes who favor dense underbrush, where they maintain full or near-full movement. Highly intelligent, they may also be magic-users, though spells can only be cast in human form. Werefoxes can charm (either persons in human form or animals in fox form) up to three times per day, lasting up to 24 hours.

Lycanthrope, Wererat.biography:
Wererats are unusual lycanthropes because their natural form is that of a large rat, and they transform into human form as needed. Intelligent and sly, they often set ambushes and prefer man-sized rat form in combat, surprising foes on a roll of 1-4 on 1d6. Wererats summon giant rats to aid them in battle, and only their bite transmits lycanthropy.

In animal form, wererats can only be harmed by magical or silvered weapons or spells, and they communicate with rats. In human form, wererats may use any weapon, speak any known languages, and be harmed by normal weapons.

Lycanthropy: Any human who loses more than half of their hit points to a wererat's bite becomes a wererat within 2d12 days. The condition kills demihumans and can only be cured by a cleric of 11th level or higher.

Lycanthrope, Wereseal.biography:
Wereseals are typically found near cold water seacoasts. The more common female wereseal is non-aggressive, but the rarer male "bull" wereseal is highly dangerous, with AC 3, HD 8, and a damaging bite attack. Females avoid combat, while males protect territory fiercely.

In animal form, wereseals can only be harmed by magical or silvered weapons, and they communicate with other seals. In human form, they may speak any known languages, use weapons, and are vulnerable to normal attacks.

Lycanthropy: Any human who loses more than half of their hit points to a wereseal’s bite becomes a wereseal within 2d12 days. The disease is fatal to demihumans and can only be cured by a cleric of 11th level or higher.

Weresharks are mermen afflicted with lycanthropy, transforming into a mako shark form in darkness. During a full moon, they must change and become bloodthirsty, losing intelligence and becoming dangerous predators. In animal form, they are harmed only by magical or silvered weapons. Malfera*.biography:
The Malfera emerges from the Dimension of Nightmares, a realm of venomous shadows where twisted dreams plague sleeping minds. Summoned only by potent magic-users or Immortals, this night-black horror—veined and eyed in red—stalks any terrain, its elephantine face, horned brow, and fanged trunk a visage of dread.

In battle, it rends with jagged pincers ([[/r 1d10 #Claw damage]] each) and bites ([[/r 1d6 #Bite damage]]), its poisonous breath forcing a save vs. poison (+3 bonus) or death with each bite. If both claws strike one foe, the victim is dragged to its slimy, tentacled chest next round, suffering [[/r 2d6 #Tentacle damage]] from acid slime until the Malfera perishes.

Immune to acid and struck only by magical weapons, it detects invisible foes and opens doors with a knock-like power. Appearing singly or in pairs ([[/r 1d2 #Malferas in lair]]), its enchanted might (HD 9, XP 2300) and treasure hoard reflect its nightmarish origin.

Terrain: Any; Dimension of Nightmares

Manscorpion (8HD).biography:
The Manscorpion, a vile blend of man and scorpion, prowls caverns, deserts, and mountains, its human-like torso atop the segmented body of a giant arachnid. Driven by malice, it roams any climate, ambushing intruders and raiding desert human enclaves for sustenance.

It wields a huge pole arm (dealing [[/r 3d6 #Pole arm damage]]) or other weapons, paired with a venomous tail strike ([[/r 1d10 #Tail damage]] + poison, save vs. poison or die, paralysis for [[/r 1d8-1 #Rounds paralyzed]] even if saved). Immune to its kin’s venom, it strikes with deadly intent.

Intelligent yet hostile, bands of [[/r 1d8 #Manscorpions wandering]] or lairs of [[/r 2d10 #Manscorpions in lair]] hoard rich treasures, their chaotic nature spurning alliances save with giant scorpions. A relentless foe (HD 8, XP 1750), it destroys all unlike itself.
Terrain: Cavern, Desert, Mountain

NCYNfWsqaEdOFvch.description: The saving throw against Breath Weapons is used to resist or mitigate the effects of a wide range of powerful exhaled attacks, not limited to dragons. This includes attacks like a dragon’s fiery or icy breath, a gorgon's petrifying breath, or a chimera's elemental breath. Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. The target number for the saving throw is determined by the character’s class and level.
NCYNfWsqaEdOFvch.name: Dragon Breath

VMW4TmKdDTRGBgU1.description: The Manscorpion’s tough chitin grants exceptional defense.
VMW4TmKdDTRGBgU1.name: Chitin

VP1ijukd0hhobzqo.description: The Manscorpion’s tail stings for [[/r 1d10 #Tail damage]] + poison (save vs. poison or die, else paralyzed [[/r 1d8-1 #Rounds paralyzed]]).
VP1ijukd0hhobzqo.gmNotes: Paralysis even on successful save; immune to scorpion poison.
VP1ijukd0hhobzqo.name: Tail Sting

WYVbXscvdkLsyAwH.description: The Magic Wand saving throw is used to avoid the effects of attacks or abilities activated through magical wands, such as paralysis rays or damage-dealing beams. A successful save, rolled on a d20, indicates that the character avoids or mitigates the harmful effects. The target number to save is determined by the character's class and level, as found on the saving throw table​​.
WYVbXscvdkLsyAwH.name: Magic Wand

hklZr8GepO0gzXjr.description: The saving throw against "Stone or Paralysis" protects a character from attacks or effects that could freeze them in place (paralysis) or turn them into stone. If the saving throw is failed, the character becomes immobilized or petrified, depending on the effect. Paralysis leaves a character aware but unable to act, while petrification turns the character and their carried equipment into a stone statue. The duration or permanence of these effects is specified by the source, and successful saving throws avoid them entirely​​​.
hklZr8GepO0gzXjr.name: Turn to Stone or Paralysis

hm0xR9HMwp7Fh3tO.description: The Death Ray or Poison saving throw is a roll made by a character to resist deadly effects like instant death or paralysis from poisons, spells, or traps. The player rolls a d20 and compares it to their class- and level-specific target number on the saving throw table; success means avoiding or mitigating the harm. A failed roll often results in death (for poison) or other severe consequences, though optional rules may instead inflict substantial damage​​​.
hm0xR9HMwp7Fh3tO.name: Death Ray or Poison

oQusJE1xPpcEbWQa.description: The Manscorpion wields a huge pole arm, dealing [[/r 3d6 #Pole arm damage]].
oQusJE1xPpcEbWQa.gmNotes: May use long bow (1d6) or other weapons instead.
oQusJE1xPpcEbWQa.name: Pole Arm

yRhYnZPEwFTkqayG.description: The saving throw for Spells or Magic Staff includes resistance against magical effects cast by rods, staves, wands, or through spells. A successful save, rolled on a d20, often reduces or negates the spell's effects entirely. This saving throw is applicable to numerous magical attacks, such as charm spells, fireballs, or paralysis effects, and covers damage, control, or debilitating conditions caused by magical devices or spellcasters. The target number for success is based on the character's class and level.
yRhYnZPEwFTkqayG.name: Spells or Magic Staff

Manticore.biography:
A manticore is a terrifying monster with the body of a lion, bat-like leathery wings, a tail ridged with spikes, and the face of a man equipped with sharp fangs. Manticores inhabit wild mountain ranges and are known for their lethal tail spikes.

These creatures can shoot up to six spikes per round, even while flying, with effective ranges of **50'/100'/180'**. The manticore has 24 spikes in total and regrows two spikes per day. Known for tracking and ambushing humans, manticores often wait until their prey is resting before attacking with a volley of spikes.

Terrain: Mountain.
Load: 3,000 cn at full speed, 6,000 cn at half speed.
Barding Multiplier: x 2.

Medusa.biography:
A medusa appears as a human female with live snakes for hair. The gaze of a medusa is petrifying, turning creatures to stone if they fail a saving throw vs. turn to stone. The effect targets only one creature per round. The reflection of a medusa is safe to look at, and a medusa seeing her own reflection must save or be petrified.

In combat, a medusa makes a single attack roll for all her snake bites. If they hit, the victim takes 1d6 damage and must save vs. poison or die within one turn. Medusae often disguise themselves with hoods to trick victims into looking directly at them. Attackers who avoid her gaze suffer a -4 penalty on attack rolls while the medusa's snake attack gains +2 to hit. Due to her magical nature, a medusa has +2 on all saving throws vs. spells.

Terrain: Hill, Open

Mek (11HD).biography:
Meks, towering metallic constructs 15 to 25 feet tall, roam any terrain as relics of a vanished race of insectoid sorcerers. Crafted with insect-like features—barrel chests, barbed, double-jointed limbs—some mimic giants or lizards, serving as guards for masters or wandering chaotically to assail all in their path.

Striking twice with heavy limbs for [[/r 1d6*10 #Limb damage]] each, they unleash a 20' paralyzing breath cloud, forcing a save vs. breath weapon each round or paralysis for [[/r 1d3 #Turns paralyzed]]. Cold slows them to half speed, but only disintegrate pierces their immunity to other spells.

Unintelligent yet responsive to simple commands when mastered, they appear singly ([[/r 1 #Meks encountered]]), their alignment shifting from lawful servitude to chaotic rampage without guidance. Their treasures vary, hoarded from fallen foes (HD 11, XP 2700).
Terrain: Any

Mek (15HD).biography:
Meks, towering metallic constructs 15 to 25 feet tall, roam any terrain as relics of a vanished race of insectoid sorcerers. Crafted with insect-like features—barrel chests, barbed, double-jointed limbs—some mimic giants or lizards, serving as guards for masters or wandering chaotically to assail all in their path.

Striking twice with heavy limbs for [[/r 1d6*10 #Limb damage]] each, they unleash a 20' paralyzing breath cloud, forcing a save vs. breath weapon each round or paralysis for [[/r 1d3 #Turns paralyzed]]. Cold slows them to half speed, but only disintegrate pierces their immunity to other spells.

Unintelligent yet responsive to simple commands when mastered, they appear singly ([[/r 1 #Meks encountered]]), their alignment shifting from lawful servitude to chaotic rampage without guidance. Their treasures vary, hoarded from fallen foes (HD 15, XP 3750).

Merman.biography:
Mermen, water-breathing humanoids of the ocean, blend human torsos with the tails of large fish, thriving in coastal waters where they hunt fish and harvest kelp. Common across the seas, they form small hunting parties or vast underwater villages, mirroring the roles of human NPCs in aquatic realms.

Armed with spears, tridents, or daggers, they strike with skill, dealing damage by weapon type (e.g., [[/r 1d6 #Weapon damage]] for spear). Leading their kind are those of greater prowess, while standard Mermen wield 1 Hit Die, their resilience honed as novice fighters.

Hunting in groups of [[/r 1d20 #Mermen in party]], with villages of [[/r 1d3*100 #Mermen in village]], they guard their homes with trained marine beasts. Intelligent and neutral, they hoard vast treasures, their presence a staple of oceanic life.

Friendly with elves, halflings, and druids, they shun human settlements, dwelling in adapted strongholds.

Appearing in groups of [[/r 1d6 #Metamorphs wandering]] or lairs of [[/r 1d20 #Metamorphs in lair]], their morale holds at 8, rising to 10 with a leader. Intelligent and often Chaotic, they hoard variable treasures, their shapeshifting versatility a constant threat.

Mimic Shifter.biography:
Mimic Shifters are man-sized shape-changing creatures known for their intelligence and malevolent nature. They can transform into the exact form of any human, demihuman, or humanoid they see (up to 7 feet tall). After assuming the form of their target, they aim to kill the original person and take their place, often using stealth and deception to avoid alerting others.

Once in disguise, they attack the group from within, often when the party is already engaged in combat. Mimic Shifters are immune to sleep and charm spells and save as 8th-level fighters due to their magical resilience. Upon death, they revert to their natural form—a hairless, genderless humanoid with pale, rubbery skin.

Mimic Shifters can establish a limited telepathic link with their intended victim, quickly learning everything their target knows. However, they cannot use memorized spells of spellcasting victims. Spellcaster Mimic Shifters are rare but can cast spells in any form they take.

**Terrain:** Any.

Minotaur.biography:
The Minotaur stalks caverns and ruins, a towering beast 7 to 9 feet tall with a man’s form crowned by a bull’s head and hide. Driven by a ferocious temperament, it roams tunnels and mazes, preying on humans and attacking anything its size or smaller with relentless pursuit as long as its quarry remains in view.

In battle, it either gores and bites for [[/r 1d6 #Gore damage]] and [[/r 1d6 #Bite damage]], or wields a weapon—favoring spears, clubs, or axes—with a +2 damage bonus from its brute strength (e.g., [[/r 1d6+2 #Weapon damage]] for spear). When armed, it forgoes its natural attacks, relying solely on the weapon’s might.

Semi-intelligent, some Minotaurs wield tools, while rare, clever ones may cast spells. Roaming in bands of [[/r 1d6 #Minotaurs wandering]] or lairs of [[/r 1d8 #Minotaurs in lair]], they hoard modest treasures, their chaotic nature a constant threat in shadowed depths.

Terrain: Cavern, Ruins

Mujina.biography:
The Mujina haunts regions where humans dwell, its natural form a chilling mimicry of humanity—featureless, with a smooth, egg-like face devoid of eyes, nose, ears, or mouth. A magical creation born to torment mankind, it crafts illusions to don any visage, often posing as an unassuming human until the moment it strikes.

Possessing uncanny strength, it wields two-handed weapons—save lances, pole arms, or crossbows—in each hand with equal prowess, dealing [[/r 1d6 #Weapon damage]] or more by type. Its blank face, revealed at will, terrifies foes: those of 5 HD or less flee for [[/r 1d3 #Rounds of fear]] at triple speed, while stronger beings must save vs. wands or join them in panic.

Cunning and hateful, the Mujina infiltrates adventurer bands as a loyal retainer, biding its time before robbing them blind and vanishing. Appearing in groups of [[/r 1d4 #Mujinas wandering]] or [[/r 1d4 #Mujinas in lair]], it speaks Common, its own tongue, and Chaotic, its loathing for human individuality driving its treachery.

Terrain: Any, where humans are found

Mule.biography:
A mule is a crossbreed between a horse and a donkey, known for its stubbornness. If provoked, a mule may either bite or kick in self-defense but cannot be trained to attack. Mules are particularly strong for their size and can carry heavy loads for their owners, moving at half speed when overloaded.

Mules can accompany adventurers into dungeons if permitted by the DM. When found alone, they might belong to an NPC party nearby.

Terrain: Any

Mummy*.biography:
Mummies are undead creatures created from the bandage-wrapped remains of nobles or guardians, usually lurking in ruins or tombs. Tasked with protecting their tombs, they will relentlessly pursue trespassers.

Upon seeing a mummy, characters must make a saving throw vs. paralysis or become frozen in fear until the mummy is out of sight. The mummy’s touch causes 1d12 damage and inflicts a disease that prevents all magical healing and reduces natural healing to 10% of normal. This disease can only be cured magically.

Mummies are only damaged by spells, fire, or magical weapons, and even then, these deal half damage. Mummies are immune to sleep, charm, and hold spells.

Terrain: Ruins

Neanderthal.biography:
Neanderthals, often called cavemen, roam hills, mountains, and prehistoric wilds in family groups, their squat, robust frames boasting large bones and powerful sinew. With apelike visages marked by prominent brow ridges, they dwell in caves and caverns far from human settlements or in hidden 'lost world' enclaves.

In combat, they hurl spears or swing stone axes, clubs, or hammers, each strike bolstered by a +1 damage bonus from their brute strength (e.g., [[/r 1d6+1 #Weapon damage]] for spear or club). Shy yet not inherently hostile, they avoid humans but stand firm if provoked, favoring lawful kin like dwarves and gnomes while despising goblins, kobolds, and ogres—the latter attacked on sight.

Living in groups of [[/r 1d10 #Neanderthals wandering]] or lairs of [[/r 1d4*10 #Neanderthals in lair]] with two leaders, they hunt cave bears, keep white apes as companions, and hoard modest treasures. Groomed and clad properly, they might pass for humans, though their grasp of Common remains rudimentary.
Terrain: Hill, Mountain; Any (prehistoric)

Neanderthal, Leader.biography:
Neanderthal Leaders tower over their kin, standing up to 10 feet tall with squat, muscular builds and apelike features—large brows framing fierce eyes. Found in hill, mountain, or prehistoric cave lairs far from human reach, they guide family groups with an almost distinct racial presence.

Wielding larger stone axes, clubs, or hammers, they strike with a +1 damage bonus from their immense strength (e.g., [[/r 1d8+1 #Weapon damage]] for axe), leading hunts against cave bears and keeping white apes as pets. Lawful in nature, they befriend dwarves and gnomes, loathe goblins and kobolds, and attack ogres without hesitation, rarely engaging humans unless threatened.

Two Leaders—one male, one female—oversee lairs of [[/r 1d4*10 #Neanderthals in lair]], their prowess evident in combat and leadership (HD 6, XP 950). Shy yet resolute, they amass treasures, and might mimic human guise if groomed, though their speech in Common falters.

Nekrozon.biography:
Lurking in the swampy depths of the wilderness, the Nekrozon looms as a formidable beast, its massive buffalo-like body crowned with a long neck, a boar’s fierce head, and a lengthy tail. Known in ancient tales as a 'catoblepas,' a name now lost to time, it haunts these boggy realms with a deadly presence.

It strikes with the bony tip of its tail, inflicting [[/r 1d6 #Tail damage]] and carrying a 50% chance to knock down and stun its target for [[/r 1d6 #Rounds stunned]] (save vs. paralysis to resist). Its gaze, a 60-foot magical death ray, activates only if it lifts its head—a 1-in-4 chance each round—killing instantly unless a save vs. death ray prevails. Accidental eye contact on complete surprise (1 on 1d6) brings unavoidable death.

Impervious to energy drains, death rays, and instant-death effects except through raw damage, the Nekrozon roams alone or in small groups of [[/r 1d3 #Nekrozons in lair]], guarding modest treasures amidst the mire.

Terrain: Swamps

Nightshade, Nightcrawler (25HD)*.biography:
The Nightshade, Nightcrawler slithers forth as a monstrous, jet-black worm, 100 feet long and 10-15 feet wide, its eyeless maw sensing all—seen or unseen—through eldritch power. Forged or summoned by greater evils for dire purposes, it prowls any terrain, its unbroken obsidian hue a mark of death’s intent.

Daylight hinders it with a -4 attack penalty, while its aura spoils all consumables within 120', chilling the air as a warning to the wise. Immune to illusions, wands, poison, charm, hold, cold, spells below 6th level, and weapons below +3, it halves dragon breath damage (quarter with a save), regenerating [[/r 3 #Hit points per round]]. It silently wields charm person, invisibility, haste, confusion, cloudkill (21st-level magic-user), darkness, hold person, cause disease, dispel magic, and finger of death (21st-level cleric) at will.

Its bite rends for [[/r 2d10 #Bite damage]] and its tail stings for [[/r 2d4 #Sting damage]], both poisoned (-2 save penalty). A 19-20 bite swallows, draining 1 level per round (no save, negated by protection from evil), while the sting has a 1-in-8 death chance. It shrinks one foe within 60' per round (save vs. spells or 1' size, +4 to hit thereafter), summons undead every 4 hours (1d6: 1-3 shade, 4-5 haunt, 6 hand druj), resists turning with a save vs. spells, and hoards swallowed treasures.
Terrain: Any

The Nightshade, Nightcrawler slithers forth as a monstrous, jet-black worm, 100 feet long and 10-15 feet wide, its eyeless maw sensing all—seen or unseen—through eldritch power. Forged or summoned by greater evils for dire purposes, it prowls any terrain, its unbroken obsidian hue a mark of death’s intent.

Daylight hinders it with a -4 attack penalty, while its aura spoils all consumables within 120', chilling the air as a warning to the wise. Immune to illusions, wands, poison, charm, hold, cold, spells below 6th level, and weapons below +3, it halves dragon breath damage (quarter with a save), regenerating [[/r 3 #Hit points per round]]. It silently wields charm person, invisibility, haste, confusion, cloudkill (21st-level magic-user), darkness, hold person, cause disease, dispel magic, and finger of death (21st-level cleric) at will.

Its bite rends for [[/r 2d10 #Bite damage]] and its tail stings for [[/r 2d4 #Sting damage]], both poisoned (-2 save penalty). A 19-20 bite swallows, draining 1 level per round (no save, negated by protection from evil), while the sting has a 1-in-8 death chance. It shrinks one foe within 60' per round (save vs. spells or 1' size, +4 to hit thereafter), summons undead every 4 hours (1d6: 1-3 shade, 4-5 haunt, 6 hand druj), resists turning with a save vs. spells, and hoards swallowed treasures.
Terrain: Any

5kK4QlP50w55S2Pw.description: The saving throw against "Stone or Paralysis" protects a character from attacks or effects that could freeze them in place (paralysis) or turn them into stone. If the saving throw is failed, the character becomes immobilized or petrified, depending on the effect. Paralysis leaves a character aware but unable to act, while petrification turns the character and their carried equipment into a stone statue. The duration or permanence of these effects is specified by the source, and successful saving throws avoid them entirely​​​.
5kK4QlP50w55S2Pw.name: Turn to Stone or Paralysis

EnJV5YQpgX8DHf1i.description: The Death Ray or Poison saving throw is a roll made by a character to resist deadly effects like instant death or paralysis from poisons, spells, or traps. The player rolls a d20 and compares it to their class- and level-specific target number on the saving throw table; success means avoiding or mitigating the harm. A failed roll often results in death (for poison) or other severe consequences, though optional rules may instead inflict substantial damage​​​.
EnJV5YQpgX8DHf1i.name: Death Ray or Poison

MSBMopIdZgBhyhiA.description: The Magic Wand saving throw is used to avoid the effects of attacks or abilities activated through magical wands, such as paralysis rays or damage-dealing beams. A successful save, rolled on a d20, indicates that the character avoids or mitigates the harmful effects. The target number to save is determined by the character's class and level, as found on the saving throw table​​.
MSBMopIdZgBhyhiA.name: Magic Wand

XB9JFZk1BQTil8QO.description: Every 4 hours, the Nightshade, Nightcrawler summons lesser undead (1d6: 1-3 shade, 4-5 haunt, 6 hand druj).
XB9JFZk1BQTil8QO.name: Summon Undead

eBlAsUYDArtdie6u.description: The saving throw against Breath Weapons is used to resist or mitigate the effects of a wide range of powerful exhaled attacks, not limited to dragons. This includes attacks like a dragon’s fiery or icy breath, a gorgon's petrifying breath, or a chimera's elemental breath. Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. The target number for the saving throw is determined by the character’s class and level.
eBlAsUYDArtdie6u.name: Dragon Breath

jtCcifU8oMfLg7A8.description: The Nightshade, Nightcrawler bites with deadly force, dealing [[/r 2d10 #Bite damage]] plus poison (-2 save penalty).
jtCcifU8oMfLg7A8.name: Bite

Nixie.biography:
Nixies, delicate water sprites standing 3 feet tall, grace rivers and lakes with their ethereal beauty, their light blue, green, or gray-green skin shimmering faintly. Kin to the forest folk—centaurs, dryads, actaeons, and their ilk—they craft lairs in the deepest aquatic hollows, shunning the surface unless necessity calls.

These beings prefer evasion over conflict, wielding a potent charm cast collectively by ten Nixies to ensnare intruders. A failed saving throw vs. spells binds the victim to a year of watery servitude, sustained by a daily water breathing spell each Nixie bestows upon her thrall. Should battle arise, they strike with small tridents or daggers, dealing [[/r 1d4 #Weapon damage]], and may summon a giant bass to aid them.

Dwelling in communities of [[/r 2d20 #Nixies in lair]], Nixies blend cunning and grace, their high intellect guiding their subtle defenses within their watery realms.

Terrain: River/Lake

Nobles are members of the ruling class, often fighters of high skill and authority. They typically wear plate mail and carry shields, as well as the finest weapons available.

Nobles usually travel with a **squire** (a 2nd-level fighter), as well as **retainers** and **hirelings** of various types, who handle their affairs. Their social rank may range from barons to dukes, and their titles depend on the campaign setting.

When encountered, a noble may be part of a larger retinue or military force, often in command of several other men.

Hit Dice: 3-8

Nomad.biography:
Nomads are wandering tribespeople, often seen in the desert or steppes. They may be peaceful traders or fierce raiders, depending on their alignment. Small groups of nomads may be found hunting or foraging, while larger groups form large camps, with leaders of higher levels guiding them.

Desert nomads are often mounted on camels or horses, equipped with lances, bows, and leather armor. Steppe nomads similarly favor bows, leather armor, and lances, but are mounted on horses.

For every 25 nomads, there is a 2nd-level fighter leader, while for every 40, there is a 4th-level fighter. Larger groups may be led by a 5th-level or 8th-level chieftain, with clerics and magic-users also sometimes present.

Weapons and Armor: Lances, bows, and leather armor.
Leadership: Nomad bands may be led by higher-level fighters, clerics, and magic-users, depending on the size of the group.
Terrain: Desert, Steppe.

Normal Human.biography:
Normal Humans represent the everyday folk who shun the call of adventure, lacking the specialized training of character classes yet sometimes boasting General Skills tailored to their lives. Found across settled lands, they embody the common populace—peasants, children, housewives, workers, artists, villagers, townsfolk, fishermen, and scholars.

Their resilience varies by age, health, and trade, with hit points selected rather than rolled, ranging from 1 for a frail child or ailing beggar to 7 for a robust blacksmith. In combat, they wield a single weapon—its damage dictated by type—though most play little role in grand tales, their lives too mundane to stir the threads of heroism.

Certain professions elevate their utility: merchants offer goods, soldiers lend martial aid with bolstered morale, lords wield influence, scouts provide guidance, sages share wisdom, and healers mend wounds. These exceptions aside, Normal Humans remain humble threads in the tapestry of settled existence.

Terrain: Settled

Nuckalavee.biography:
Dwelling in coastal oceans, tranquil lakes, and desolate ruins, the Nuckalavee emerges as a malevolent amphibious kin to the centaur, its form marked by a grotesque, oversized head. Its transparent skin reveals a ghastly sight—white, sinewy muscles, yellow veins pulsing with life, and dark blood flowing beneath—evoking dread in all who behold it.

This fearsome creature shrugs off fire and poison, regenerating [[/r 3 #Hit points per round]] each round, yet it recoils from crossing flowing freshwater. Its mere presence radiates terror within a 50' radius, forcing all nearby to save vs. paralysis or flee for [[/r 2d6 #Rounds of fear]], a test repeated each round they linger. Small creatures and insects with 2 hit points or less perish instantly within 120' of its aura.

In battle, the Nuckalavee rends with two claws, each dealing [[/r 3d8 #Claw damage]] plus a deadly curse—victims must save vs. death ray or perish. Every three rounds, it unleashes a chilling cone of cold, 60' long and 10' wide at the base, inflicting damage equal to its current hit points (save vs. dragon breath for half). Allied with undead, it converses freely with them, immune to their attacks unless under strict command.

Terrain: Lake (not river), Ocean (coastal), Ruins

Load: 3,000 cn at full speed; 6,000 cn at half speed

Ochre Jelly*.biography:
The Ochre Jelly lurks as a massive, ochre-hued amoeba, thriving in the dank confines of caverns and ruins. This amorphous creature shrugs off all but fire and cold assaults, its gelatinous form seeping through tiny fissures with ease.

In combat, it delivers a corrosive touch, inflicting [[/r 2d6 #Damage per round]] to bare flesh, while swiftly dissolving wood, leather, and cloth in a single round—though metal and stone remain impervious. Weapon strikes or lightning merely fracture it into [[/r 1d4+1 #Number of smaller jellies]] smaller versions, each with 2 Hit Dice and dealing half damage ([[/r 1d6 #Smaller jelly damage]]).

These smaller offshoots persist, posing continued threats unless consumed by flame or frost, the only forces capable of halting this relentless ooze.

Terrain: Cavern, Ruins

Orb Guardian.biography:
An Orb Guardian, also known as a “sphere of many eyes,” resembles a large floating ball about 4 feet in diameter, covered with tough, armor-plated skin. It has ten small eyes on stalks atop its body, each with its own unique magical power, and a large central eye positioned on the front, with a toothy mouth below.

The Orb Guardian moves by means of a slow, natural flight that cannot be dispelled. It is highly intelligent, cruel, and greedy, and speaks many languages. This creature is typically found alone but may be accompanied by 1d6 young (each with 1/10 normal Hit Dice and eye effects, dealing 1d4 points of bite damage) with a 5% chance.

The central eye of an Orb Guardian emits an anti-magic ray, which negates all magical effects within 60 feet in front of it. Magical weapons in this area are treated as non-magical, and spells cast within the area of effect are instantly disrupted. Spells cast from outside the area are ruined when they enter its range. The Orb Guardian will turn to face any character who begins spellcasting, disrupting the spell. Once the anti-magic ray is no longer directed at an object or area, magical items and effects return to their normal function.

The anti-magic ray cannot be directed above or below the creature, only straight ahead. As the ray can negate any magic, even that of the smaller eyes, the Orb Guardian cannot use its smaller eye powers on targets within this area.

When attacking an Orb Guardian, players must declare whether they are aiming at the body, the large central eye, or an eye stalk, each with distinct armor class and hit points:

  • The body has AC 0 and 50 hit points.
  • The central eye has AC 2 and 20 hit points.
  • An eye stalk has AC 7 and can withstand 12 hit points of damage. Damage to eye stalks does not contribute to killing the creature.

Small Eyes and Eyestalks: If an attack hits an eye stalk, the GM should randomly determine which stalk is damaged. A severed eye stalk is rendered nonfunctional, but partial damage does not impede its operation. Lost eyes regenerate in 2d4 days, and partially damaged stalks heal at a rate of 1 hit point per day.

The Orb Guardian can only direct four small eyes in one direction at a time and cannot target directly beneath its body. Each eye can fire a ray with a different spell-like effect once per round. The spell effects are detailed below, with reversed versions indicated by an asterisk.

Eye Powers:

  1. Charm Person (range 120')
  2. Charm Monster (range 120')
  3. Sleep (range 240')
  4. Telekinesis (range 120', up to 5,000 cn weight)
  5. Flesh to Stone* (range 120')
  6. Disintegrate (range 60')
  7. Cause Fear* (range 120')
  8. Slow* (range 240')
  9. Cause Serious Wounds* (range 60')
  10. Death Spell (range 240')

Terrain: Caverns, Ruins.

Orb Guardian, Undead*.biography:
An Undead Orb Guardian is similar in appearance to its living counterpart but is actually a construct created for a specific malevolent purpose. These creatures are never naturally undead; instead, they are crafted for dark deeds. The Undead Orb Guardian resembles a large floating sphere, about four feet in diameter, covered with tough, armor-plated skin. It has ten small eyes on stalks, each capable of a different magical effect, and a large central eye on the front of its body with a toothy mouth below. The creature moves using natural (non-magical) flight, and it is highly intelligent, capable of speaking many languages. A cleric of 25th level or higher can recognize it as an undead being upon sight.

Undead Orb Guardians are immune to normal, silver, and even +1 magical weapons; only a magical weapon of +2 or greater can harm them. They are unaffected by charm, hold, and sleep spells, as well as illusions, death rays, and poison. Their bodies regenerate 3 hit points per round once damaged. If reduced to 0 hit points, they shift into gaseous form and cannot regenerate until resting for 1 hour in complete darkness, after which their regeneration resumes. They often maintain areas of continual darkness around their lairs.

These creatures can assume gaseous form at will. In this state, they lose access to their special abilities but cannot be harmed except by magic that affects air. Their bite inflicts 2d10 points of damage and causes a two-level energy drain, similar to that of a vampire.

The central eye of an Undead Orb Guardian projects a ray of reflection, bouncing any spell cast at it back to the caster. Similarly, any attempt to turn undead from this direction reflects back onto the cleric, who must succeed in a saving throw vs. spells or flee in terror for 2d6 rounds. The creature will typically turn to face any spellcasting character to utilize this defense. This reflective ray only works in the front arc and cannot be directed above or behind the creature.

When attacking, the player must specify whether they are targeting the body, the large eye, or an eye stalk. Each part has different armor classes and hit points:

  • The body has AC -4 and 90 hit points.
  • The central eye has AC -2 and 30 hit points.
  • Each eye stalk has AC 3 and can withstand 20 hit points of damage. Damage to the eye stalks does not count toward destroying the creature.

Small eyes and eyestalks: Each small eye can be used once per round, and only three eyes can focus in one direction (forward, backward, etc.). If the target is above the creature, all ten eyes can be used. The Undead Orb Guardian often uses only two eyes per round unless it perceives a serious threat. If an eye is destroyed, it can regrow in 1d4 + 1 hours, although this regeneration is slower than that of the body.

Eye Powers:

  1. Animate Dead (range 60')
  2. Charm (as vampire, 120' range, with a -2 penalty to the saving throw)
  3. Continual Darkness (range 120')
  4. Death Spell (range 120')
  5. Energy Drain (1 level, as wight)
  6. Energy Drain (2 levels, as spectre)
  7. Paralysis (as ghoul, range 60'; elves are immune to this ray)
  8. Animate Object (range 60')
  9. Dispel Magic (26th level)
  10. Telekinesis (4,000 cn)

Terrain: Cavern, Ruins.

Orc.biography:
Orcs are ugly, humanlike creatures with a blend of animal and human features. Most orcs have human-shaped bodies, but many display bestial facial traits and sharp teeth.

Orcs are nocturnal omnivores and prefer to live underground. When forced to fight in daylight, they suffer a -1 penalty on attack rolls. They are short-tempered and tend to dislike other living creatures.

Each group of orcs has a leader with 8 hit points who gains a +1 bonus on damage rolls. If this leader is killed, the morale of the group drops to 6 instead of 8. Orcs are fearful of creatures larger or stronger than themselves but can be driven to fight by their leaders.

Orcs are frequently used as soldiers by Chaotic leaders, whether human or monster. They prefer using swords, spears, axes, and clubs in battle but cannot operate mechanical weapons like catapults, except for their leaders who understand such devices.

Orc tribes come in many varieties, with each tribe containing as many females as males and at least two children ("whelps") for every two adults. The leader of a tribe is a chieftain with 15 hit points, who fights as a 4 Hit Dice monster and gains a +2 bonus on damage rolls. For every 20 orcs in a tribe, there is a 1 in 6 chance that an ogre is present. Additionally, there is a 1 in 10 chance of a troll ally living in the tribe's lair.

Orc, Chieftain.biography:
The Orc Chieftain reigns over its tribe, a menacing humanoid with animalistic features—bestial teeth and rugged visage—etched into a manlike frame. Preferring the shadows of underground lairs, it leads its nocturnal kin, shunning daylight where its attacks suffer a -1 penalty.

Wielding a favored weapon—sword, spear, axe, or club—with a +2 damage bonus, the Orc Chieftain strikes as a 4 Hit Dice foe despite its base resilience. It governs a tribe of [[/r 1d6*10 #Orcs in lair]], bolstered by a leader per group, maintaining a morale of 8 that drops to 6 if the group leader falls, reflecting their dread of mightier adversaries unless compelled.

Chaotic overlords harness Orc Chieftains to fortify armies, leveraging their grasp of mechanical devices like catapults, a skill beyond lesser orcs. Tribes harbor equal numbers of females and at least two whelps per adult pair, with chances of ogre or troll allies enhancing their lairs.

Orc, Leader.biography:
The Orc Leader stands as a formidable figure among its kin, a brutish humanoid blending animalistic traits with a manlike form, often sporting beastly facial features and jagged teeth. Nocturnal by nature, it thrives underground, leading its group with a harsh temperament and a distaste for outsiders.

In daylight, the Orc Leader suffers a -1 penalty to attack rolls, wielding a preferred weapon—sword, spear, axe, or club—with a +1 bonus to damage rolls due to its prowess. It commands a group of 2d4 orcs in the wild or up to [[/r 1d6*10 #Orcs in lair]] in a lair, maintaining a morale of 8; if slain, the group’s morale drops to 6, reflecting their fear of stronger foes unless driven by its authority.

Chaotic leaders, both human and monstrous, often enlist Orc Leaders to bolster their forces, exploiting their inability to use complex machinery like catapults, a skill reserved for these commanders alone. Each tribe includes females and whelps, doubling the adult count with at least two children per pair.
Terrain: Wilderness (any)

Phantasmal Panther.biography:
The Phantasmal Panther resembles a large black feline with six legs and a pair of 6-foot long tentacles protruding from its shoulders. It uses these tentacles, which are edged with horn-like tips, to attack. The Panther's skin has a peculiar ability to bend light, causing it to appear several feet away from its actual position. This grants all attackers a -2 penalty to their attack rolls, while the Panther receives a +2 bonus to all saving throws.

If severely wounded (6 hit points or less), the Panther will resort to a ferocious bite attack, gaining a +2 bonus to hit and dealing 1d6 points of damage.

Phantasmal Panthers are carnivorous, preying primarily on smaller herd animals in forested and jungle regions. They may occasionally wander into dungeons due to curiosity or the lure of food. They generally avoid conflict with adventurers unless driven by extreme hunger.

These creatures harbor an intense animosity towards Blink Hounds, attacking them and anyone in their vicinity on sight. It is believed that the two species originate from a distant plane and are embroiled in an endless interdimensional war.

Terrain: Hill, Jungle, Woods.

Phantom, Apparition*.biography:
The Apparition emerges as a semi-transparent humanoid figure, reminiscent of a wight, haunting ruins across various locales while shunning sunlight, though untroubled by magical illumination. It lurks in an ethereal state initially, immune to damage from the Prime Plane until it materializes for combat.

Upon sighting, all within 120' must resist its fearsome presence with a saving throw vs. spells or flee in terror; creatures of 3 Hit Dice or less succumb automatically, refusing to return. It begins by conjuring a swirling, semi-transparent mist—10' high, 20' radius—entrancing those within who fail a saving throw vs. spells, rendering them inactive for up to 12 rounds or until the mist dissipates.

Once it ensnares a victim, the Apparition solidifies (AC 0) and attacks with bony claws, gaining a +4 bonus to hit and dealing [[/r 1d6+2 #Claw damage]] per strike, favoring entranced targets. Resistant to clerical turning (saving throw vs. spells reflects 'T' results), it hoards its victims’ treasures nearby. Victims slain by it rise as Apparitions within a week unless a dispel evil precedes a raise dead spell; otherwise, they fade into undeath.
Terrain: Ruins

Phantom, Shade*.biography:
The Shade, an undead humanoid wielding a dagger, haunts indoor and underground ruins, evading sunlight but unfazed by magical light. It begins in an ethereal state, untouchable from the Prime Plane until it strikes.

With a 90% chance to surprise, it emerges through walls or doors, its gaze forcing a victim within 120' to save vs. spells or flee (3 HD or less fail automatically, refusing to return). Its initial assault brandishes the dagger, requiring a save vs. death ray or instant death from horror.

Materializing (AC 0), the Shade slashes with its dagger for [[/r 3d4 #Dagger damage]], favoring nearby targets. Resistant to turning (saving throw vs. spells reflects 'T' results), it retreats ethereally if threatened or morale falters, stashing its victims’ treasures close by.
Terrain: Ruins

Phantom, Vision*.biography:
The Vision, a collective of 2d4 lost souls resembling battle-fallen humanoids, haunts a fixed 500-square-foot ruin, shunning sunlight but indifferent to magical light. Ethereal at first, it’s intangible until it materializes.

Upon encounter, its souls wail within 90', forcing a save vs. spells or inducing despair for [[/r 1d10+10 #Rounds of despair]], with continuous saves required. After [[/r 1d3 #Rounds of wailing]], it rises (AC 0), attacking with [[/r 2d4 #Spectral swords]] 2-8 swords as a 12 HD entity, each dealing [[/r 1d8 #Sword damage]]. Damage is collective across its forms.

Resistant to turning (saving throw vs. spells reflects 'T' results), it vanishes for [[/r 1d6 #Hours of disappearance]] if turned, reappearing in its domain. Bound to its area, it moves at 40' per round via swords, dropping treasure upon destruction.
Terrain: Ruins

Pirate.biography:
Pirates are sea raiders who engage in plundering ships and coastal towns. They are often Chaotic fighters known for their cruelty and lawlessness. Pirates are organized into crews based on ship size, with 10 to 80 pirates per ship.

For every 30 pirates, there is a 4th-level fighter leader, and each ship has a 5th-level captain. For every fleet of 100 or more pirates, there is an 8th-level commander. Larger pirate fleets may also include an 11th-level Pirate Lord, with a 75% chance of an accompanying 9th-10th level magic-user.

Pirates often wear **leather armor**, wield **swords**, and some may carry **crossbows**. Pirates may carry treasure with them or have maps to buried treasure.

Pixie.biography:
Pixies are small humanoid creatures with insect-like wings. Standing at only 1-2 feet tall, they are distantly related to elves. Pixies are naturally invisible unless they wish to be seen or are detected by magic.

Unlike creatures affected by invisibility spells, pixies can attack while remaining invisible. They always gain surprise when doing so, and cannot be attacked in the first round of combat. In subsequent rounds, attackers can attempt to strike them, but with a -4 penalty to attack rolls.

Pixies live in secluded wilderness communities and rarely attack humans unless provoked. They may, however, assist friendly adventurers with guidance through the wilderness or lead them to hidden locations.

Terrain: Woods.
Flight Limitation: Pixies can fly for up to three turns before requiring a full turn of rest.

Plasm, Giant*.biography:
A plasm looks like a human- or giant-sized skeleton made of elemental matter. There are four types, one for each element, composed of elemental material and ectoplasm (solid ether). It cannot safely exist outside the Ethereal Plane or wormholes, losing 1 Hit Die per round from energy drain on other planes, vanishing when dead.

It feeds on its element, regenerating 1 hit point per round, and gains Hit Dice from elemental magic attacks (e.g., a 9th-level fireball adds 9d8 HP to a fire plasm).

Immune to poison and normal weapons, magical weapons deal only their 'plus' damage (e.g., sword +4 deals 4 damage). Only magical weapons and opposing elemental attacks harm it.

Once per turn, it can spend 10 hit points to create a 30' diameter acid cloud lasting [[/r 1d6 #Rounds of cloud duration]], dealing 20 damage (save vs. dragon breath for half), often used when fleeing.
Terrain: Ethereal Plane, Wormholes (only)

This lake- or sea-dwelling dinosaur has a heavy body featuring two sets of flippers (forelimbs and hind limbs) and a long neck. It grows to about 30'-50' long, about half of which is neck. They are aggressive and may rise up underneath a small vessel and tip its sailors and passengers into the sea, resulting in a feeding frenzy of plesiosaurs and other marine creatures.

Purple Worm.biography:
Purple Worms are huge, slime-covered creatures over 100' long and 8' to 10' in diameter. These monsters tunnel through the earth, burrowing up from the ground to feed on surface-dwelling creatures. They attack by biting and stinging with their tails. If the bite attack roll is 4 or more greater than needed (or a 20), they swallow man-sized or smaller creatures whole, dealing [[/r 3d6 #Damage per round swallowed]] damage each round thereafter. A tail sting requires a save vs. poison or the victim dies. Underground, tunnel size may limit attacks. When tunneling to approach, they have a 1 in 4 chance to surprise, but [[/r 1d4+1 #Rounds until tail free]] rounds pass before the tail is free.
Terrain: Cavern, Ruins, Swamp, Woods (dense)

Rat, Giant.biography:
Rats are clever rodents that can eat meat, grain, sawdust, almost anything. They usually avoid humans and won’t attack unless summoned (e.g., by a wererat) or defending their lair. Rats are adept swimmers and may attack in water. They fear fire and flee from it unless compelled to fight by a summoning creature. Some rats carry diseases; each bite has a 1 in 20 chance of infection (roll per hit), requiring a save vs. poison to avoid. Failure may lead to death in [[/r 1d6 #Days until death]] days (1 in 4 chance) or a month of sickness, preventing adventuring.
Giant rats, 3' long or more with gray or black fur (morale 8), are found in dark dungeon corners and near undead.

Revener.biography:
The Revener appears as a human figure with skeletal hands and a skull head adorned with flowing white hair. It prowls dark, underground caverns, dust-filled tombs, and crypts. When it touches a victim, it permanently drains one sense unless the victim succeeds on a save vs. spells, reducing the loss to a temporary [[/r 2d6 #Rounds of sense loss]] rounds. Lost senses are chosen or random, with subsequent hits affecting different senses. A restore spell can recover one lost sense. Effects include: Taste (cannot identify tastes like potions), Smell (immune to odors, -1 to surprise), Hearing (deaf, unclear speech affecting spellcasting), Touch (Dexterity -4, elves lose secret door detection), Sight (blindness), Sixth Sense (blocks ESP, crystal balls, telepathy). Morale is typically 10.
Terrain: Ruins

Rhagodessa.biography:
The Rhagodessa is a giant spiderlike carnivore, roughly the size of a small horse, with an oversized yellow head and mandibles, and a dark brown thorax. It has five pairs of legs, the front pair ending in suckers that grasp prey. A leg hit deals no damage but sticks the victim, pulling them to the mandibles for an automatic bite in the next round. These nocturnal hunters operate only in darkness, typically residing in caves and capable of climbing walls.
Terrain: Cavern, Ruins; Hill, Mountain, Woods (after dark)

Robber Fly.biography:
The Robber Fly is a 3' long giant insect that closely resembles a bee with its black and yellow stripes. However, unlike bees, the Robber Fly is a carnivore that hunts its prey with patience and stealth. From a distance, it can easily be mistaken for a giant bee.

Robber Flies prefer to prey on giant bees but may also attack adventurers when hungry. They are immune to bee poison. These flies often hide in shadows, waiting to ambush their prey, gaining surprise on a roll of 1-4 on 1d6. They can leap up to 30 feet to bite their targets.

Special Abilities: Surprise attack.
Terrain: Open, Ruins, Woods.

Roc, Small.biography:
Small rocs are massive birds of prey that resemble eagles. They are highly lawful creatures and can be hostile toward neutrals or chaotic beings. Rocs prefer solitude and attack any intruders near their nests unless approached with care.

Rocs make their nests in the highest mountains and may have 1d6 eggs or young if encountered in their lair. They can be trained as riding beasts if captured as chicks.

Terrain: Mountains (lair), Any (hunting).

Rustadillo.biography:
The Rustadillo resembles a giant armadillo with a long tail and two long front antennae. It’s attracted to the smell of metal, feeding on the rust it creates. When its antennae hit a target, any nonmagical metal armor or weapon crumbles to rust instantly. Magical metal items lose one 'plus' per hit unless they resist (10% chance per 'plus'—e.g., a shield +1 has a 10% chance to survive). The creature can be struck by any weapon type without harming the weapon if the body is hit, not the antennae.

Terrain: Cavern, Ruins

Salamander, Flame.biography:
The flame salamander is a fearsome creature from the elemental plane of Fire. It resembles a massive snakelike lizard, measuring between 12 and 16 feet in length, with bright orange-yellow and orange-red scales. While native to the plane of Fire, it is sometimes found in very hot environments on the Prime Plane, such as volcanoes or desert lands.

In combat, it attacks with its claws and powerful bite. Additionally, the heat it radiates is intense and affects all creatures within 20 feet, inflicting 1d8 points of heat damage per round. The salamander itself is completely immune to all forms of fire.

Flame salamanders are mortal enemies of frost salamanders and will attack them on sight.

Terrain: Plane of Fire.

Salamander, Frost.biography:
The frost salamander is a massive six-legged lizard hailing from the elemental plane of Air. It has white or blue-white scales and prefers frozen wastelands, glaciers, and icy tundra when found on the Prime Plane. The creature is extremely dangerous and has the ability to attack with all four of its claws and a vicious bite.

In addition to its physical attacks, the frost salamander radiates an aura of extreme cold. All creatures within 20 feet of the salamander take 1d8 points of cold damage per round. The salamander itself is immune to all forms of cold.

Like its fiery counterpart, the frost salamander is the mortal enemy of flame salamanders and will attack them on sight.

Terrain: Plane of Air.

Sasquatch.biography:
Sasquatches are shy, low-intelligence humanoids dwelling deep in dark woods and high mountains. These tall, apelike creatures have crested heads, large feet, and thick hair—dark brown in woodlands, white in mountains. Omnivorous, they occasionally slay animals but prefer plants and berries. Though not aggressive with a low morale of 6, they defend their cavern lairs fiercely, raising their morale to 11 when protecting their home, using clublike fists. They can also throw boulders up to 50 feet. If both claws hit one victim, they hug for an additional 4d6 damage. Known as 'Bigfoot' in woods and 'Yeti' or 'Abominable Snowman' in mountains, they can rarely be spellcasters.
Terrain: Mountain, Woods

Sea Hag*.biography:
The Sea Hag is one of the most repulsive creatures known, feared for its horrifying appearance and deadly powers.

Horrific Visage: Any creature that sees the Sea Hag or comes within 10 feet must make a saving throw vs. spells at -6 or flee in terror for 1d20+5 rounds.

Energy Draining Touch: A Sea Hag’s touch acts as an energy drain, reducing the victim’s level by one (as a wight). Additionally, it causes disease (no saving throw).

Undead Control: Though not undead itself, the Sea Hag can command undead as if it were a 16 HD undead creature.

Weaknesses & Resistances: A Sea Hag can only be harmed by silver or magical weapons.

Environment & Lair: It lives primarily in shallow coastal waters but can venture onto land for up to three hours at a time.

Companions: Often accompanied by undead or other sinister creatures.

Terrain: Ocean (Coast).

Shadow.biography:
Shadows are ghostly, intelligent creatures that are noncorporeal in nature, resembling real shadows. Despite their eerie appearance, they are not undead. These beings dwell in dark, foreboding places such as dungeons, dense forests, or ancient ruins. Shadows are immune to damage from non-magical weapons and can only be harmed by enchanted arms.

They possess the ability to alter their shape slightly, which helps them blend into their surroundings. Due to their elusive nature, shadows are difficult to detect and often surprise their opponents, achieving surprise on a roll of 1-5 on a d6.

When a shadow attacks and hits, it inflicts both physical damage and drains 1 point of Strength from the victim. This Strength loss lasts for 8 turns. If a creature’s Strength is reduced to zero, they are transformed into a shadow themselves.

Shadows are immune to sleep and charm spells. While they share some characteristics with undead creatures, they are not classified as undead and cannot be turned by clerics.

Common Terrain: Ruins, Woods.
