Shrew, Giant.biography:
Giant Shrews resemble large, brown-furred rats with elongated snouts. They are adept at burrowing, climbing, or jumping up to 5 feet. Their weak eyes render them unaffected by light or darkness, relying instead on radar-like squeaks to 'see' within 60 feet as effectively as normal sight. A silence 15' radius spell blinds them, reducing their AC to 8 and imposing a -4 penalty on attack rolls due to confusion. These shrews always take initiative on their first attack and gain a +1 bonus on initiative rolls thereafter. Their ferocious bites target the head and shoulders, forcing victims of 3 Hit Dice or less to save vs. death ray or flee in fear. Though they only eat insects and vegetable matter, their nervousness and aggression lead them to attack anything within 20 feet.
Terrain: Open, Ruins, Woods

Shrieker.biography:
Shriekers resemble giant mushrooms, thriving in underground caverns and capable of slow movement. They react to light within 60 feet or movement within 30 feet by emitting a piercing shriek lasting for [[/r 1d3 #Rounds of shrieking]] rounds. Each round of shrieking prompts a 1d6 roll by the DM; a result of 4-6 means a wandering monster hears the noise and arrives in [[/r 2d6 #Rounds until arrival]] rounds. This shriek can stun small animals, particularly birds and bats, which the shriekers then crawl over to consume through feeding orifices on the bottom of their stalks. They also scavenge carrion left nearby.
Terrain: Cavern, Ruins

Slug, Giant (10 HD).biography:
The Giant Slug is a massive, boneless creature inhabiting underground caverns and dungeons. Its rubbery body can squeeze through any opening 5' x 5' or larger. Due to its elasticity, attackers cannot apply strength bonuses to damage, blunt weapons only inflict magical damage (none if non-magical), and edged weapons deal half damage plus magical adjustments. The fighter's Smash option inflicts no additional damage. It can bite with its sharp tongue or spit acid, preferring the latter. The acid attack has a range of 5' per Hit Die, with the first shot always missing to range in, followed by normal attacks. Victims hit by acid take damage equal to the slug's current hit points, halved with a successful save vs. dragon breath, and failed saves may destroy equipment. Giant slugs can have up to 20 Hit Dice.
Terrain: Cavern, Ruins

Spectral Hound*.biography:
Spectral Hounds are eerie creatures hailing from the Dimensional Vortex, the void between dimensions. They manifest in this world as ghostly, pale, translucent dogs with eyes like formless pools of utter blackness. Renowned for their tracking prowess, they pursue their quarry relentlessly for days. These hounds are bred and trained by interplanar beings such as elemental rulers, amirs, and pashas as hunting animals, often deployed to track intrusive adventurers back to their home planes or, conversely, potentially charmed by adventurers to hunt villains across dimensions. They never appear on the Prime Plane unless summoned by greater powers.
In combat, a spectral hound bites, dealing damage and triggering a save vs. spells. A successful save limits the damage to 2d6, but failure initiates a gradual fading process, turning the victim translucent like the hound over 24 hours. The victim's equipment remains unaffected, but once fully faded, they cannot hold normal items, hear, or speak to unfaded beings, perceiving normal things as translucent while faded entities appear solid. A dimension door spell can restore a faded character to normal at any time by allowing them to step through it. Spectral hounds can only be harmed by silver or magical weapons, not normal ones, and are immune to fire- and cold-based spells.
Terrain: Any; including all dimensional planes

Spectre.biography:
Ghostly spectres are powerful undead creatures, appearing as translucent beings with evil expressions and fiery eyes. Once human or demihuman, they now serve greater evil forces, often as lieutenants.

Spectres can only be harmed by magical weapons; silver weapons are ineffective. They are immune to sleep, charm, and hold spells, as are all undead.

The spectre’s touch attack deals 1d8 damage and drains two experience levels from the victim. A character slain by a spectre will rise the next night as a spectre under its control.

Terrain: Ruins

Sphinx.biography:
The Sphinx is a majestic, winged creature with a lion's body and a human's face, often found in dry climates but can be encountered anywhere, typically as a guard. Chaotic sphinxes might be very territorial. Both male and female sphinxes are extremely intelligent spellcasters; the female acts as a 12th-level cleric, the male as a 12th-level magic-user, with all saves against their spells at a -4 penalty. In combat, they use claws, bites, or spells, but their roar is their most formidable attack, usable twice per day. This roar affects all within 120 feet, forcing a save vs. spells at -4 or flee in fear for 1d6 turns. Within 60 feet, victims also face paralysis, being stunned for 1-6 rounds if they fail another save. Within 10 feet, the effects include fear, stun, 6d6 damage, and deafness for 1d10 turns without a save. Sphinxes are immune to 1st, 2nd, and 3rd-level spells and nonmagical weapons. They enjoy puzzles, riddles, and trivia; solving these can avoid combat or gain friendship. When more than one sphinx is encountered, they are either a mated pair or with cubs.
Terrain: Any; especially Desert
Load: 6,000 cn at full speed; 12,000 cn at half speed.
Barding Multiplier: x3

Any creature bitten by a black widow spider must make a saving throw vs. poison or die within one turn. Its webs can be burned away, and adventurers can try to break free as per the *web* spell.

Spider, Giant (Tarantella).biography:
The tarantella is a massive, 7-foot-long spider with hairy legs and a venomous bite. Its bite doesn't kill directly but causes the victim to experience painful, spasm-like movements that resemble a frantic dance.

If the victim fails a saving throw vs. poison, they are forced to dance uncontrollably for 2d6 turns. Onlookers who witness the dancing must also make a saving throw vs. spells or start dancing in the same manner. Dancing victims suffer a -4 penalty to attack rolls, while attackers gain a +4 bonus to hit them. After 5 turns of dancing, victims collapse from exhaustion and become helpless to further attacks.

Terrain: Ruins, Woods.

Spider, Planar (10 HD).biography:
The Planar Spiders are intelligent, plane-traveling arachnids with an enigmatic civilization. They can move through planes and dimensions at will, often appearing from the Ethereal plane to attack and then 'shift' back. Most commonly encountered with 5 Hit Dice, leaders can have up to 12. Their home plane is described as a world covered with cities made of imperishable white webs, though no such cities have been found. These spiders speak Common and are not inherently hostile, capable of interactions similar to human NPCs. In combat, they gain automatic initiative when shifting planes, and there's a 75% chance they cannot be attacked before leaving unless the opponent is hasted. Their bite deals damage and requires a saving throw vs. poison at -4, or death, though they can choose to not use their poison. Planar spiders might carry 1d3 magical or 1d4 nonmagical but odd items. Rarely, some are spellcasters, either clerics or magic-users up to 9th level, with extra asterisks for XP calculation based on spellcasting ability. Spellcasting spiders cannot phase out in the same round they cast a spell.
Terrain: Any

Spider, Planar (9 HD).biography:
The Planar Spiders are intelligent, plane-traveling arachnids with an enigmatic civilization. They can move through planes and dimensions at will, often appearing from the Ethereal plane to attack and then 'shift' back. Most commonly encountered with 5 Hit Dice, leaders can have up to 12. Their home plane is described as a world covered with cities made of imperishable white webs, though no such cities have been found. These spiders speak Common and are not inherently hostile, capable of interactions similar to human NPCs. In combat, they gain automatic initiative when shifting planes, and there's a 75% chance they cannot be attacked before leaving unless the opponent is hasted. Their bite deals damage and requires a saving throw vs. poison at -4, or death, though they can choose to not use their poison. Planar spiders might carry 1d3 magical or 1d4 nonmagical but odd items. Rarely, some are spellcasters, either clerics or magic-users up to 9th level, with extra asterisks for XP calculation based on spellcasting ability. Spellcasting spiders cannot phase out in the same round they cast a spell.

Spirit, Druj*.biography:
Druj appear as horrifically animated body parts like hands, eyes, or skulls, capable of moving or floating. They are very intelligent and strongly evil, often more dangerous than they appear. Druj can split into four identical forms once per night, each poisonous and capable of attacking separately, with one form maintaining spell-like abilities. These abilities mimic cleric spells like darkness, silence 15' radius, cause disease, animate dead, and finger of death, cast as if by a 16th-level cleric, requiring concentration. Druj poison their victims on touch, causing immediate death if a saving throw vs. poison fails. Their presence spoils all consumable items within 30 feet, including normal food, water, holy water, rations, and magical potions, without allowing a saving throw, paralyzing plants and small insects, leading to their death if the spirit remains for over an hour. Druj can sense invisible things and attack them without penalty. They become invisible and nearly powerless at dawn, regaining powers at dusk, capable of traveling up to 24 miles per day in daylight.
Eye: An eye druj darts to touch and poison its opponent without dealing damage, can gaze once per round to paralyze for 1d4 turns within 30 feet, automatically touching paralyzed victims.
Hand: A hand druj inflicts 1d4 damage on hit, then holds on, causing damage each round equal to the victim's AC (ignoring dexterity and shield bonuses) plus 1d4; negative AC still causes 1d4 damage per round.
Skull: A skull druj floats to bite, causing a save vs. spells or be frozen with fear, allowing automatic bites for 2d4 damage, with each bite requiring a save vs. poison.
The first successful turn attempt forces a druj's components to reunite for 1d4 + 1 rounds, after which further turning is handled normally. Druj are encountered singly unless commanded by a lich or higher Sphere of Death entity, where they might appear with other druj parts.
Terrain: Any (usually Barren Lands and Ruins)

Spirit, Odic*.biography:
An Odic spirit travels up to 24 miles daily, settling into a plant by night. It is visible from 300 yards due to its purplish light with a 20-foot radius, causing energy drain to any living being within, reducing their level if they fail a save vs. spells. Once settled, it cannot move until daybreak but animates parts of the plant for attacks, such as branches or leaves. The longest branch or vine reaches out up to 30 feet, attacking as a 16 HD monster, dealing 1d12 damage plus poison. Leaves can move up to 1 mile away, surprising with a 90% chance, and can charm on touch, drawing victims towards the odic where they suffer a -4 penalty to saves against energy drain. If the plant lacks detachable parts, other portions are animated similarly, up to 6 at once, each with a charm ability. Odics can possess plantlike monsters, gaining their abilities in addition to its own, potentially leading to the monster's death from level drain even if the save against possession is successful. Odics become invisible and nearly powerless at dawn, regaining powers at dusk.
Terrain: Any (usually Barren Lands and Ruins)

It can leap once per turn to a 60-foot range, guaranteeing all three attacks hit if it surprises and leaps, each requiring a save vs. poison. Revenants are resistant to turning; if a 'D' result is indicated, they can save vs. spells to negate the effect, but a 'turn' result forces them to retreat for 1d4 turns. Sporacle.biography:
The Sporacle is a monstrous creature that at first glance mimics the appearance of a beholder: a 5-foot diameter floating ball with a large central eye and gaping mouth, surrounded by tentacles. It has six eyes evenly spaced around its body. The sporacle regenerates rapidly in fresh water at a rate of 3 hit points per round, allowing lost body parts to regrow. If a severed tentacle is placed in fresh water, it will grow into a new sporacle in one hour, which is their primary method of reproduction, making them commonly found near water sources.
It attacks with 12 extendable tentacles and a bite, preferring humanoids. It uses its tentacles first, each dealing 1 damage and requiring a save vs. paralysis; failure leads to delayed paralysis after one round, lasting one turn unless cured. The bite is only used once all tentacles are destroyed, dealing 2d10 damage. The sporacle spins rapidly in combat, using all tentacles each round against one or two opponents. It cannot use spells or magical items and is of average intelligence (10).
The creature is immune to blunt weapons, sound-based effects, poison, paralysis, and charms. It can be damaged by edged or missile weapons (except slings); spells that cause damage affect only its tentacles, destroying one tentacle per die of damage. When reduced to 0 hit points, its body disintegrates, sending tentacles flying in all directions.
Terrain: Cavern

Sprites are small, winged humanoids standing about 1 foot tall. They are related to pixies and elves. Though they tend to be shy, sprites are curious creatures with a strange sense of humor.

Once a stirge successfully hits a target (inflicting 1d3 points of damage), it attaches itself to the victim. From there, it drains 1d3 points of blood per round until the victim is dead.

Thug (10HD).biography:
The Thug, also called an Assassin, belongs to the Pragmati, a ruthless organization of rogue executioners who take contracts for murder. Unlike the Thieves' Guild, the Pragmati operate independently, using secrecy, extortion, and violence to maintain power.

Stealth & Deception: Thugs rely on disguise, ambush tactics, and treachery. They use garrotes, poison, and cheap but effective weapons, avoiding traceable magical items. They rarely attack openly, preferring to strike unseen and disappear without a trace.

Guild Secrecy: Thugs work in the shadows, often blackmailing former clients. They will betray anyone, even their employers, for the right price.

Combat & Assassination: Thugs have the abilities of a thief of the same level, including move silently, hide in shadows, and climb walls. When setting an ambush, they roll 1-3 on 1d6 for surprise instead of the usual 1-2. If they gain surprise, they may attempt an instant kill with a base 50% ± (5% per HD difference). If the attempt fails, they deal normal weapon damage.

Weakness & Strategy: If wounded or exposed, thugs prefer retreat over combat. They sometimes work as guards for high-ranking criminals, occasionally partnering with bandits or renegades, though often without their allies' knowledge.

Terrain: Any; Settled.

Thug (11HD).name: Thug (11HD)

Thug (12HD).biography:
The Thug, also called an Assassin, belongs to the Pragmati, a ruthless organization of rogue executioners who take contracts for murder. Unlike the Thieves' Guild, the Pragmati operate independently, using secrecy, extortion, and violence to maintain power.

Stealth & Deception: Thugs rely on disguise, ambush tactics, and treachery. They use garrotes, poison, and cheap but effective weapons, avoiding traceable magical items. They rarely attack openly, preferring to strike unseen and disappear without a trace.

Guild Secrecy: Thugs work in the shadows, often blackmailing former clients. They will betray anyone, even their employers, for the right price.

Combat & Assassination: Thugs have the abilities of a thief of the same level, including move silently, hide in shadows, and climb walls. When setting an ambush, they roll 1-3 on 1d6 for surprise instead of the usual 1-2. If they gain surprise, they may attempt an instant kill with a base 50% ± (5% per HD difference). If the attempt fails, they deal normal weapon damage.

Weakness & Strategy: If wounded or exposed, thugs prefer retreat over combat. They sometimes work as guards for high-ranking criminals, occasionally partnering with bandits or renegades, though often without their allies' knowledge.

Terrain: Any; Settled.

Thug (1HD).biography:
The Thug, also known as an Assassin, is a rogue executioner who operates outside the law, taking on murder-for-hire contracts. These criminals form a secret faction known as the Pragmati, meaning "the practical people." Unlike the Thieves' Guild, the Pragmati are not backed by rulers or adventurers, making them ruthless and unpredictable.

Stealth & Deception: Thugs rarely engage in fair fights, preferring ambushes, disguise, and silent assassination. They use poison, garrotes, and concealed weapons, often leaving behind no evidence of their crimes. They favor cheap, disposable tools over magical weapons.

Guild Secrecy: Thugs keep their identities hidden and rarely deal directly with outsiders. Even those who hire them are later extorted under threat of exposure, kidnapping, or assassination.

Combat & Assassination: A thug possesses the same special abilities as a thief of equal level, such as move silently, hide in shadows, and climb walls. When ambushing, they roll 1-3 on 1d6 for surprise instead of the usual 1-2. If they surprise a target, they may attempt an instant kill with a base 50% ± (5% per HD difference). If the attempt fails, they deal normal weapon damage.

Weakness & Strategy: If discovered, thugs will usually flee unless they outnumber their enemies. They sometimes work with bandits and renegade factions, though often without the knowledge of their allies.

Thug (4HD).biography:
The Thug, also called an Assassin, belongs to the Pragmati, a ruthless organization of rogue executioners who take contracts for murder. Unlike the Thieves' Guild, the Pragmati operate independently, using secrecy, extortion, and violence to maintain power.

Stealth & Deception: Thugs rely on disguise, ambush tactics, and treachery. They use garrotes, poison, and cheap but effective weapons, avoiding traceable magical items. They rarely attack openly, preferring to strike unseen and disappear without a trace.

Guild Secrecy: Thugs work in the shadows, often blackmailing former clients. They will betray anyone, even their employers, for the right price.

Combat & Assassination: Thugs have the abilities of a thief of the same level, including move silently, hide in shadows, and climb walls. Thug (8HD).biography:
The Thug, also called an Assassin, belongs to the Pragmati, a ruthless organization of rogue executioners who take contracts for murder. Unlike the Thieves' Guild, the Pragmati operate independently, using secrecy, extortion, and violence to maintain power.

Stealth & Deception: Thugs rely on disguise, ambush tactics, and treachery. They use garrotes, poison, and cheap but effective weapons, avoiding traceable magical items. They rarely attack openly, preferring to strike unseen and disappear without a trace.

Guild Secrecy: Thugs work in the shadows, often blackmailing former clients. They will betray anyone, even their employers, for the right price.

Combat & Assassination: Thugs have the abilities of a thief of the same level, including move silently, hide in shadows, and climb walls. When setting an ambush, they roll 1-3 on 1d6 for surprise instead of the usual 1-2. If they gain surprise, they may attempt an instant kill with a base 50% ± (5% per HD difference). If the attempt fails, they deal normal weapon damage.

Weakness & Strategy: If wounded or exposed, thugs prefer retreat over combat. They sometimes work as guards for high-ranking criminals, occasionally partnering with bandits or renegades, though often without their allies' knowledge.

Terrain: Any; Settled.

It has the ability to change its skin color to camouflage itself in woods or poorly lit dungeons, surprising its prey on a roll of 1-3 on 1d6. Its tongue can extend out to 15 feet, dragging victims of dwarf size or smaller towards its mouth for biting. On a natural 20 attack roll, it can swallow small prey whole, dealing [[/r 1d6 #Damage per round after being swallowed]] damage each subsequent round.

Toad, Rock/Cave.biography:
The Rock Toad, or Cave Toad, resides in rocky, cold areas like high mountains or frozen deserts. It's roughly the size of a large dog, weighs about 150 pounds, and has a hard, bumpy shell like a turtle. Its most notable feature is its multi-faceted, hypnotic eyes that compel creatures to save vs. paralysis or be paralyzed for [[/r 2d4 #Rounds paralyzed]] rounds. After death, its eyes emit a feeble light for [[/r 1d3 #Hours of light]] hours, but lose their hypnotic effect. It attacks with a horny, beaked mouth.
Terrain: Cavern; Desert (cold), Mountain

Treant.biography:
A treant is an intelligent, 18-foot-tall creature resembling a tree, with recognizable facial features. It has two large branches that act as arms with hands and walks on root-like feet. Treants are guardians of the forest and plant life, and they are friendly with other intelligent forest creatures like actaeons, centaurs, and dryads. They speak a slow and complex language and are distrustful of anyone who uses fire.

Treants blend in almost perfectly with normal trees, and all encounters with them begin at a distance of 30 yards or less. They surprise on a roll of 1-3 on a d6 due to their camouflage. Although normal weapons can harm them, blunt weapons (such as maces) only inflict 1 point of damage per hit, plus any magic and strength bonuses.

In combat, a treant attacks with two powerful branch strikes. Additionally, it has the ability to animate nearby trees, commanding up to two within a 60-foot radius to move and fight as treants with a movement rate of 30' per turn. The treant can choose new trees to animate each round, allowing it to adapt to the flow of battle.

Terrain: Woods

Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. Triceratops.biography:
The Triceratops is an armored, herbivorous dinosaur, akin to an elephant in temperament. This creature, measuring about 30 feet in length and weighing between 10 to 12 tons, features a distinctive collar-like armor plate around its neck for protection. Its offensive capabilities include a short horn on its snout and two long horns above its eyes, making it a formidable opponent even against large carnivorous dinosaurs.
Despite being a herbivore, the Triceratops is known for its aggressive behavior, often charging into combat. It can deliver a double-damage charge attack if it's the first attack or if it has moved 20 yards or more away from its enemy before attacking again.
Terrain: Open (prehistoric)

Troglodyte.biography:
Troglodytes are intelligent, reptilian humanoids with short tails, long legs, and spiny combs on their heads and arms. They walk upright, similar to humans, and are adept at using their hands. Troglodytes are known for their hostility towards most other species. They possess a chameleon-like ability to change color, blending into their surroundings like rock walls, which allows them to surprise opponents (on a roll of 1-4 on 1d6). Additionally, they secrete an oil that gives off a foul stench, which can nauseate humans and demihumans unless a saving throw vs. poison is successful. Nauseated characters suffer a -2 penalty to attack rolls when fighting troglodytes in melee.
Some troglodytes can be spellcasters; see the section on 'Monster Spellcasters' for more details.
Terrain: Cavern, Ruins

Troll.biography:
Trolls are tall, thin humanoids standing 8 feet tall. They possess sharp teeth, ferocious features, and mottled rubber-like skin. Trolls are carnivorous, preferring human and humanlike prey. They are found in a variety of terrains, often living in the ruins of their victims' dwellings.

Trolls are extremely dangerous due to their **regenerative powers**. Three rounds after being damaged, a troll will start to heal itself at a rate of **3 hit points per round**. Even severed limbs can crawl back to the troll’s body to rejoin. However, trolls cannot regenerate damage from fire or acid, and when attacked by these means, their morale drops to **8**.

Claw Damage: 1d6 per claw.
Bite Damage: 1d10.
Regeneration: Trolls heal 3 HP per round starting 3 rounds after damage. Severed limbs rejoin the body unless destroyed by fire or acid.
Terrain: Cavern, Wilderness (any).

Tyrannosaurus Rex.biography:
The 'tyrant lizard,' or Tyrannosaurus Rex, is the largest predatory dinosaur known, measuring at least 40 feet in length, weighing up to 8 tons, and standing about 20 feet tall. It roams 'lost world' regions, where it hunts with ferocious intent. This creature moves on its hind legs, with its massive tail acting as a counterbalance, while its small, clawed forelimbs offer little aid in combat. However, its primary weapon, its colossal jaws lined with 6-inch teeth, are devastating. The Tyrannosaurus Rex will attack any creature of man-sized or larger, focusing on the largest first. A roll of 19-20 on an attack allows it to swallow a man-sized opponent whole, dealing 2d4 damage each round until the victim is freed.
Terrain: Jungle, Open, Woods (prehistoric)

Undine*.biography:
The undine is an intelligent creature composed entirely of water, rare even in the Elemental Plane of Water, its home, and seldom encountered on the Prime Plane. Though chaotic, undines possess good intentions and despise evil. On their home plane, they typically take the form of a featureless, transparent snake but can change shape at will, often using multiple tentacles to manipulate objects. They can swim at an accelerated rate, forming a revolving coil for short bursts.
Undines are immune to poison, normal weapons, all 1st and 2nd level spells, and fire-based attacks. They can detect invisible creatures at will and use spells like detect magic, web, dispel magic, ice storm/wall, and fire to ice three times per day, as if cast by a 9th level magic-user. Their web, made of ice strands, functions like a normal web but melts harmlessly when exposed to flame.
An undine's attack involves shaping water into a 'fist' for melee combat or coiling around an opponent for constriction damage. On the Prime Plane, they resemble water elementals, becoming invisible in water and regenerating damage, but they take damage from drying out when not submerged. Unlike elementals, they are not limited by protection from evil or proximity to water.
Undines have natural enemies in the hydrax and hordes, and they are wary of air-type creatures and attacks.
Terrain: Plane of Water

2wIGNrh034dQKVa8.description:

Higher-Level Casters: Effects created by a higher-level spellcaster may resist dispelling. The chance of failure is 5% per level difference. For example, a 7th-level magic-user dispelling a spell cast by a 9th-level cleric has a 10% chance of failure.

Magical Items: This spell does not affect magical items themselves, but it can disrupt active effects they produce. For instance, dispel magic can free a person from the control of a ring of human control.
2wIGNrh034dQKVa8.name: Dispel Magic

Unicorn.biography:
A unicorn resembles a slender, graceful horse with a long, spiraling horn protruding from its forehead. Known for their beauty, no one has ever witnessed an unattractive unicorn. Though they are shy and elusive, they become fierce defenders when threatened. Only a pure maiden can speak to or ride a unicorn, forming a bond with these mystical creatures.

Unicorns possess the magical ability to teleport themselves (and a rider) up to 360' once per day. If they have a rider, their morale improves to 9. These rare beings prefer to live deep within forests, far from sentient creatures. Unicorn horns are highly prized by evil wizards for use in alchemical potions and magical research, making them targets for hunters.

Vampire* (Human).biography:
Vampires rank among the most dreaded undead in the game. They dwell in forsaken places like ruins, tombs, and crypts, emerging under the cover of night to hunt humans. These creatures are known for their ability to transform shape, their supernatural resilience, and their capacity to drain life force.
Vampires are immune to spells like sleep, charm, and hold, and can only be harmed by magical weaponry. They possess the chilling power to transform into a human guise, a dire wolf, a giant bat, or a cloud of gas, with each transformation requiring one round. No matter the form, vampires regenerate at a rate of 3 hit points per round once injured. Should their hit points reach zero, they turn into gas and escape to their coffins to heal.
In human form, a vampire can attack with a deadly touch that not only deals damage but also drains double the life energy of the victim, or use its gaze to enthrall opponents. The gaze requires a saving throw vs. spells at a -2 penalty to resist the charm. Additionally, a vampire can call forth allies within 300 feet (or 300 yards outdoors) including swarms of rats, bats, or packs of dire wolves.
A human killed by a vampire rises as one themselves three days later, under the control of their creator. Vampires can also be spellcasters.
Weaknesses: They are repelled by strongly presented holy symbols, cannot approach garlic without making a saving throw vs. poison, and are unable to cross running water except at bridges or within their coffins. During daylight, they must rest in their coffins or lose hit points, which won't regenerate until they've rested for a full day. Vampires cast no reflection, thus they shun mirrors. They can be destroyed by a wooden stake through the heart or by prolonged exposure to running water. In sunlight, they must save vs. death ray each round or disintegrate; however, a continual light spell does not have this effect. If all their resting places are blessed or destroyed, they weaken, losing hit points until they perish.
Terrain: Ruins, Tombs, Crypts

A wraith is a spectral undead entity, a pale and almost transparent mist-like figure. It is the spirit of the selfish dead, clinging to the Prime Plane by draining life from the living.

Defenses: A wraith is immune to sleep, charm, and hold spells. It can only be harmed by silver or magical weapons, but silver weapons inflict half damage.

Energy Drain: The touch of a wraith drains 1 experience level from its victim and also deals 1d6 damage. Any creature slain by a wraith will rise as a new wraith in one day, under the control of its slayer.

Terrain: Barren Lands, Ruins.

Wyvern.biography:
A wyvern is a fearsome creature that resembles a two-legged dragon, complete with a long, spiked tail. Unlike true dragons, wyverns lack forelimbs and are usually seen in hues of brown, red, or rust-red. They are commonly found in mountainous regions or dense forests, though they can be encountered in many environments.

In battle, wyverns use both their bite and their venomous stinger. The creature arches its tail over its head to sting enemies in front of it, and those struck by the stinger must make a saving throw vs. poison or die. Wyverns are carnivorous, often preying on large herd animals such as elk and moose, but they will not hesitate to attack humans if encountered.

Terrain: Mountain, Woods.
Load: 3,500 cn at full speed; 7,000 cn at half speed.
Barding Multiplier: x 3.

Yellow Mold.biography:
Yellow Mold is a dangerous fungus that covers an area of up to 100 square feet. It does not move, but reacts aggressively when disturbed.

It is immune to all damage except fire, which deals normal damage. Torches inflict 1d4 damage per round when used to burn it. Yellow mold can dissolve wood and leather in an instant, but it cannot harm stone or metal.

When touched, there is a 50% chance that it releases a cloud of spores in a 10' x 10' x 10' area. Anyone caught in the spores takes 1d6 damage and must make a saving throw vs. death ray or suffocate within six rounds.

Terrain: Cavern, Ruins.

Zombie.biography:
Zombies are mindless, undead humans or demihumans reanimated through evil magic. They are commonly used by malevolent rulers and dark spellcasters as disposable soldiers or laborers. Their vacant expressions and shuffling gait make them eerie guardians of crypts and ancient ruins.

Unlike living creatures, zombies are immune to sleep and charm spells. They can be turned by clerics but otherwise follow their commands without question. While they can be harmed by normal weapons, their sluggish reflexes make them always lose initiative in combat.

Zombies are often stationed to guard treasures, standing eerily silent until disturbed. When encountered in lairs, they may be found in large numbers, standing vigil over long-forgotten tombs.

Terrain: Ruins.
